content:
Posted: August 11, 2013
												Knights of Pen & Paper, originally for iOS, is a turn-based RPG with a novel concept: you take on the role of real-life players in a tabletop game.  The camera is set behind a table where up to five of your characters are seated, with the dungeon master on the other side leading you through the story.  Dialogue tends to be humorous and frequently goes out of character.The game begins with character creation, where you must assign your players a real-life persona and one of a dozen traditional RPG classes, each with four skills.  The actual gameplay takes place around your table, as if you’re in the middle of all the action, and consists of traveling to locations on a world map and completing quests, which are really just more battles in disguise.  In fact, the entire game is simply one battle after another and becomes very repetitive, very fast.As expected, level-ups provide stat bonuses and allow you to upgrade your skills and wear better equipment.  Armor and weapons may only be improved at the blacksmith, but each character has four additional slots for equipping various accessories.  In addition to in-game shops, there is a “real-life” shop where you may purchase snacks that provide temporary buffs for your players, as well as decorations and furniture that confer permanent bonuses.Overall, Knights of Pen & Paper is passable in the context of mobile gaming but completely forgettable when compared to quality games on the PC platform.  Considering the price is $9.99 on Steam vs a mere $2.99 on iOS and Android, it’s borderline offensive that the devs left in-app purchases in the game, allowing you to buy gold with your Steam wallet funds.  Such a shameless exhibit of its mobile origins is a fitting red flag for a game that also fails to break away from the shallow, repetitive gameplay those origins typically entail.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												I admit, I miss tabletop gaming. I miss the DM trying to kill off my characters. I miss creating ridiculously out-of-the-box characters. Heck, I miss the days of popcorn, Mountain Dew, and just hanging out and rolling some dice. Those days have been gone for me quite some time, and yet playing a little game called Knights of Pen and Paper reminded me of those good old days.Knights of Pen and Paper attempts to mimic tabletop gaming for an accessible audience. Players start by selecting three noobs to join the adventuring party, along with their class and starting skill. Like any tabletop RPG, as the adventuring party explores, kills baddies, and completes quests, they earn experience to level up and gain more skills. Each party member gets one skill point every time they level up and can only put points into one of four skills. While this creates simplicity for those unfamiliar with RPGs, it doesn't provide a lot of variety.In fact, variety is what Knights of Pen and Paper struggles with throughout its twenty hour campaign. Although the backgrounds mimic an 8-bit style, there isn't much in terms of detail or design. The soundtrack loops, but it feels like there's only three tracks in the entire game. Although there's plenty of classes in the game, many of them are locked and the requirements for unlocking them appear random. The base classes — paladin, mage, cleric, etc. — while classic, are trapped with only four skills, which wouldn't be the case in tabletop gaming.While variety isn't the game's strong suit, accessibility is. It provides a simple turn-based battle system wherein players can select between attack, skill, defend, item, and flee. This makes for an easy learning experience, but it lacks any real depth that a tabletop game has. The game is also surprisingly grindy, and while it does a great job of teaching players what to expect in encounters (usually enemies three to five levels higher than the adventuring party), it's a bit crazy how much players will have to stop and grind because it's not entirely on par with the party's level. It feels like the developers set out to make a simple RPG to give players the feel of tabletop gaming, but the combat could have benefited from actual dice rolls on screen to indicate whether or not the player's characters succeeded or fail in their actions. However, with the grindy combat, perhaps adding dice rolls would have just made everything take longer than provide more accessibility. Still, the combat lacks depth and it needs something else to make it a more engaging process.Dice rolling does exist within Knights of Pen and Paper, it's just not as frequent as it should be. Dice rolls occur when players travel between areas, failures leading to battles, successes leading to safety. Dice rolls occur when players are mining for grindstones or moving through dungeons. These elements are done well and are fairly straightforward, but this game would really benefit if it was implemented into all actions, especially if its goal is to mimic tabletop games. What's further disappointing is the campaign itself. While the writing is charming and hilarious, the majority of the quests are either escort missions, collecting items, slaying some bad dudes, or traveling from place to place for plot purposes. The amount of backtracking in this game is brutal and inexcusable, and even the adventuring party complains about it. It goes back to that problem of accessibility versus variety — on one hand, the campaign should be easy to learn and follow along, on the other hand there should be more to do than then the standard affair. The charm in the writing, and even its awkward translation errors, can only go so far and will likely leave veteran RPG gamers wanting something more substantial.However, Knights of Pen and Paper does succeed in its overall atmosphere. Players get the sense of gamers hanging out, bantering, and asking to pass the Mountain Dew. There is an overall sense that the Dungeon Master is out to kill the adventuring party, and the back and forth within the writing really does work well. The graphics and music, though overly simplistic, are vibrant and give the feeling that players are on an adventure and there is loot to be had. The game is also a fantastic time waster because in its lack of depth it success at being the type of mindless game where players find themselves going, "just one more quest." Considering all of the game's flaws, it admittedly succeeds in the one area that for some people matters most: it's actually fun.There are some perks in Knights of Pen and Paper's PC release that differ from the original mobile version. For starters, it allows players to leave party members at the tavern, and bring a new adventurers into the party. They can roll for a new character and not feel like they have to start their entire campaign from scratch. There's also an extended campaign for those who want to explore more of what the game has to offer, and there's tons of new dungeons and loot to acquire. The main campaign can be completed in around twenty hours, with the extended campaign offering quite a bit of replay value. There's also tons of items that can be purchased in shops that can give added bonuses to various stats, which is a nice cosmetic feature.Knights of Pen and Paper is a sweet little throwback to the days of pen and paper gaming, but its simple approach may not be enough to entice every RPG gamer. Yes, the combat is simplistic, but it's fast and easy to roll with. Sure, the story is simple, but it's cute in its presentation. Knights of Pen and Paper's imperfections are many, and yet it's completely easy to sink time into. It's straightforward in its approach and yet, despite its flaws and frustration, I kept playing. Knights of Pen and Paper will never offer gamers a deep experience, but it offers mindless gameplay that admittedly can keep you coming back for more.Recommended

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Knights of Pen and Paper is a fantasy RPG, which plays like tabletop RPGs. The twist is that you're playing as both the dungeon master and the players. Basically that means you can decide yourself what kind of quests you want (to some extent) and how difficult you want to make the fights by choosing how many enemies you want to fight against. And because the game is like tabletop RPGs, there are several situations where you'll throw a virtual D20 dice.When you first start the game you get to choose from about 10 characters to be the players and 5 classes for them. Each character has a different passive bonus that increases some attributes, which actually leads to choosing the characters based on the bonuses and the class you're going to pick. When starting a new game you get to choose 2 players for free and the remaining 3 seats in the table you can fill by buying the players with in-game gold. You can swap the players in places that have a tavern.If I remember correctly, you first have 5 classes available, but you can unlock a few more by completing side-quests. You can only have one of each class, so for example you can't have 5 warriors as your party. You wouldn't want to either. The reason being that each class has its purpose. Some classes are healers, some are tanks and the rest are either melee fighters or spellcasters of some description. Each class has 4 skills, which are either passive or spells and skills that you can use during combat. The passive skills usually boost some attribute, but some of them also have special stat boosts like life steal. The active skills are pretty basic fantasy RPG skills. You can increase one of the skills every time you level up, which just made the skills more powerful or increased the attribute bonus. So it isn't very deep skill system.The combat is turn based and the players and the enemies all have a box either on top of or below the sprite, which shows the number of their turn. On the player's turns you choose to either attack, use a skill/spell, use an item, defend or run away from the battle. You quite rarely want to use anything other than a skill or spell, because those are the most effective way for beating the enemies. As I mentioned earlier, you get to choose how many and what kind of enemies you want to fight against. Once you buy a certain item from a special shop you can fight 7 enemies at a time, but before that the maximum was 5, I think. I bought that item very early on and didn't check the maximum amount before that. The enemies you can choose from vary quite a lot and you can often choose to fight tougher elite monsters, which give better rewards.I thought the combat was quite fun, but it got kinda boring after 8 hours because in the end it was just the same thing over and over again. At least they kept things fresh with different enemies. The difficulty ramped up quite a lot after about halfway into the game, when the enemies suddenly became very high-leveled compared to the players. Surprisingly enough, I could survive against much higher level enemies than my players were provided I only fought against 3 at a time. It could take a long time to kill them all, but I still could do it. I suppose I played it quite safe since most of the time I fought battles I knew I could win and as a result my whole party died only 3 times during the time I played the game.When you're not in combat you can choose from several options depending on your location in the world. In almost every place you can choose to rest, start a quest specific to the location, use items, check the equipment of the players or travel to some other place. Cities usually also have shops for buying potions and equipment, a tavern and a blacksmith. The blacksmith can upgrade your equipment, but you shouldn't do that until you have increased the blacksmith's level enough for the odds to be on your side. The upgrading is chance based and it happens by throwing the dice. The range of "winning" numbers increases as the blacksmith levels up, which makes it easier to win. It's also a good idea to have level 16 players, because then you can equip items that decrease the equipment upgrading cost. I wasted several hundreds of in-game gold before I found about those items.Moving in the world happens by opening the world map and then choosing the location. Traveling costs some gold and every time you move on the map, you throw the D20 dice and depending the roll you might get a random battle. That would get annoying very quickly, if you had to fight some low level monsters when moving around the starting area with high level players, but luckily the chance for the random battle depends on the players' levels and the levels of the monsters in the area you're travelling to. You can also a buy an item that permanently increases your dice rolls by 1, which makes it impossible to get random battles in low level areas. I thought the time it took to travel between each place was a bit too long, but you could reduce that to half if you had a certain game master active.Quests were quite repetitive and not very fun. There is basically 3 types of quest: kill x amount of certain monsters, escort/deliver something and "fetch" some items by going to a certain place and killing the enemies there for the items and then return to the place where you started the quest. On the upside the quests gave a lot of experience. There were also some story quests as this game has a (boring) story about saving the pen and paper world. I think the dialog should have been funny, but I didn't find it funny. There were quite many references, but those weren't funny either. At one point I stopped caring about the story entirely and just skipped through the dialog. I just didn't find it interesting at all.The game also has a special store that you can access anytime you're not in combat or in the middle of some conversation. The store has items like furniture, which boost something permanently, and snacks, which give a boost that only lasts for about 15 minutes. You can switch between the furniture you have bought without having to buy them again. I usually switched them based on the situation I was in. Everything bought in this store transferred to other saves too, so you only had to buy the stuff once.I believe the game was originally designed for phones and tablets as there is an in-game store, from which you can buy in-game gold for real money. However, using the in-game store is never required and it can be completely ignored. Once you reach a certain point in the game, you can easily get around 300 gold from a fight that lasts for a minute. The in-game gold is transferred between saves so you can have a save for farming gold for the other save. The real money store in the game seems to be a thing that makes some people skip the game entirely, even though you never have to use the store.The graphics are 2D pixel art and the sounds effects are pretty old-school bleeps and bloops. There is no voice acting, so you have to read through all the dialog. I thought the music was repetitive so I ended up muting it.Overall I thought it was pretty enjoyable game and I was quite addicted to it for a while. I played it for 21 hours in total, which included me first going through half the game and then starting a new save to get couple of achievements. I finished the story in the second game I started and also beat the optional boss. I also got every achievement aside from the 3 broken ones. The boring story and the in-game real money store are definite cons, but the rest of the game is fun even without very deep character development or combat.

Posted: June 13, 2014
												There isn't much to this game; it's just a simple, humorous 8-bit turn base game. There is a lot of hilarious commentary and for the most part character development is nice. I know that the dialog is all pre-set, but it makes the characters pretty funny and sassy. One of my favorite aspects is the ridiculous dirty jokes made through-out the game.There's a ton (I mean A LOT) of characters and classes to choose from. There's a nice little upgrade setting that lets you have a few different moves and upgrade them. It's just like any other turn base game. It's fun, it's cheap and the developers are extremely nice and enjoy interacting with their fans; which is always great. I would definably get this game while on sale.

												This is a very simple looking RPG on the cover but once you get into it, there is plenty of min/maxing to be done. A turn based gameplay makes fits this much more than a normal action type. I love how you can swap in "team members" to the table once you purchase more seats at the table.Another thing which is probably overlooked in Knights of Pen & Paper, is the dialog of the dungeon master and the players, some really humours lines came out during my playthrough and I would really recommend anyone read through them for a giggle. The soundtracks can get fairly repetitve but what do you expect for an 8bit style game. I'm up to about twelve hours gameplay and I am still finding new things to try out. I would 100% recommend this to any RPG/Turn based fan

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												I don't know where and when I got this game...But... This game...This game is awesome!I liked the overall parody feel about it while it has a strong and solid work about delivering action and plot in moderation, getting some loud laughs from me here and there. The battle is unforgiving, so you always have to be focused, despite it being turn-based. The difficulty is adjustable in a manner "How frisky you are today?", taking on anything between 1 and 7 rats or elite monsters. The open-ended way the characters are presented lets you use your imagination. I do feel like playing a table top sheets'n'pens while playing this. Yes, the feel of every character is an illusion, but it's a very-VERY well made illusion.Another point is the building difficulty: Items give you stats that you barely see. Levels give you damage that you barely see. Hp and Mana regen is earned by tears and sweat dripping down your inner thigh. All this while enemy shamelessly uses lifesteal and applies crazy bleeding stacks. Some battles will be so tight that you will stain your undergarments a bit and still lose because of the enemy randomly preferring your rouge to your fully buffed granny paladin. You will put a sleep on a DoT'ed enemy and lose your healer because of that, and you will spend 4 times the money you earned in that battle to revive your team. You will even spend 2k on upgrading your sword and still get nothing in return because you are a looser and you will have no money to leave the god forsaken town.But... You know... That's what's good about this game... That's what's your adventure is. And you should not just accept it, but have tons of fun while at it!I would like to say thank you to the developers. I've seen a lot of attempts to do what they achieved in this game and i think they did it better than anyone else I've seen so far, including UnEpic and Magicka, the first being too far away and the second being a bit too silly. But this game, oh, this game grabs the bull by his modesty and makes him enjoy it so much that he's ashamed afterwards, but he begs for more.Highly recommend.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												This has the appearance of a nostalgic D&D tabletop setting, but is more like a poorly-translated turn-based JRPG, where tactical positioning and well-timed skill choices are not the focus. Instead, players find themselves killing hordes upon hordes of monsters to make numbers go up so they can kill bigger hordes of scarier monsters. The story tries to be humorous about a D&D group finding the line between fantasy and reality blurred with numerous shoe-horned cameos, but the writing itself is unnatural to the point that it feels like a high-schooler's fan-fiction. In fact, if you're looking for a game the emulates the D&D experience, I recommend Cardhunter, a free-to-play tactical game with better writing and more involved gameplay.Even if you're in the market for a mindless grind-a-thon, don't buy this on the PC. Opt for the mobile version instead, since the game also constantly puts you through miniscule but unskippable animations that would be more bearable if you could look out the window while they play. Hell, I'd recommend other mobile games entirely, but some people like their skinner boxes and this is one of the skinneriest boxes I've ever seen.P.S.: This game *had* micro-transactions, but those have been removed. According to an anonymous source (see comment), the microtransaction was originally forced on by a publisher. A sad case of publisher overruling developer control. The game is still a terrible grind though.

												The first 4-5 hours are great, when you are exploring the world, unlocking new classes and testing different groups. Sadly, afterwards the game becomes a massive grind of fighting the same enemies over and over, going back and forth the same places and every battle feels exactly the same...It has a lot of flavor and cool references, but still I couldn't even force myself to reach the end of the game. There's micro-transactions in-game, but honestly they don't get in the way, the massive grind at end-game and lack of interesting battles are this game's major flaws.

Posted: January 17, 2014
												I really loved the game. It took me 20 hours to complete, which includes a restart after some hours when I had unlocked more interesting characters than the starting lineup. I'll have to go back and finish it with the ones I missed in the future. The game was a lot of fun, and definitely worth the asking price. It made me smile many times, what with all those wacky references to other games and developers. I bought the Deluxe edition to support the developers as much as I could, as I had researched the game prior to buying it, and I'm glad I did. The extra gold you start with is nice (but doesn't provide any sort of advantage other than when you get a full lineup but let's face it, it doesn't matter).If you're on the fence, then just go ahead and spend the 10 euro or whatever the price is in your region. It's a fun throwback to the golden ages of gaming, and it's just well done through and through. I doubt very much you'll regret it. Don't worry about the ingame cash shop. I never used it, and NEVER had a reason to. You earn redicilous amounts of gold in this game just doing the main quest line, and the extra gold you can buy for real money is so useless, I'm puzzled why they added it at all.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												I enjoy the premise of this game, the core idea that it tries to emulate with a twist, a DnD session where you can customize and control the players and the room that the game takes place in, even the dungeon master. I will say that the game does have charm and has a good art direction, though I would say that there should have been more effort in the pixel art. However, it has both condensed and distilled the core elements of pen and paper gaming to a level which is far too simplistic for me to enjoy. The combat is shallow, the quests are repetitive, and the stats and perks are shallow and hardly feel like they matter. The UI is also highly simplistic and does not even provide important information efficiently or at all. I am sure that this is a fun bathroom game on a mobile device or something on the go, but the flaws of this game impeded my enjoyment of this game and cannot recommend this game to people who want an enthralling experience.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
The Good: Fun premise, mixing the tropes of D&D-style tabletop gaming and Final Fantasy-esque RPG combat, with the usual nods to post-Tolkien high fantasy worlds. There's a solid dose of fun pop culture references (from Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and Super Mario Brothers in the sewer dungeon, to Pirates of the Caribbean and the Creature from the Black Lagoon in the seaside areas). And it's not just gratuitious name-checking either -- all of it is properly statted out and integrated into the gameplay.The Bad: Admittedly, it's hardly ground-breaking stuff, especially if you're partial to comedy/parody RPGs. It's not quite as witty or clever as its web-based counterparts like Kingdom of Loathing[kingdomofloathing.com] or Card Hunter[game.cardhunter.com]. But even as someone who liked both those games, I wasn't disappointed -- I'm now at 10 hours play time and counting.The Ugly: Less-than-ideal game balance. It definitely appears to favor particular player/class combos over others, to the point that it's damn near impossible to last the higher levels with certain oddball party compositions, which kinda takes out some of the fun.

I thought it was a fun little game and would recommend it, because it can be picked up for next to nothing or even free and if you enjoy anything D&D related, you should at least give it a try. Get ready for a Nostalgia rush.

content:
Posted: March 26
												I really liked the design concept of the game. Ideally it gives you the freedom of exploring a vast, magical world and design your own adventure. It has the potential of becoming a tool kit for creative story telling with its pre-existing mechanics, however, that being said, all the stories within the game are all pre-written and quite limited. The game does a nice job in trying to replicate the feeling of being both in a real world and an imaginary one when playing DnD by allowing the player to purchase object in the "real world" with the gold you get in the game world while these items would aid you in games. The downside of this is that the game gets extremely grindy after some hours of playing. The characters of the game are relatively diverse, yet they only have 4 moves each, which makes the combat pattern repetitive. The style of the game is an 8-bit pixle art type, which is fine ---- gives me a feeling of Pokemon Leafgreen. The soundtrack of the game becomes really loopy, and seems rather limited. I would prehaps give the game a 6/10 as a decent time killer. A good game if on a discount (say for 3 or 4 dollars), but would not recommend buying for 10 dollars.

number of helpful: 94 of 162 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2013
												I can describe Knights of Pen and Paper as a Dungeons & Dragons simulator instead of your typical RPG. There is no exploration or movement. It is all menu and dialog based. The map is pretty segmented like a Mario map and there are not maps so much as there are quests. These quests revolve around typical and simplified RPG turn based combat. The catch is you also play your own dungeon master, so you can select your enemies to fight and how many you will fight. Its as if you're making your own busy work. The classes feel balanced, but the battles begin feel too long for the never ending grind that this game becomes. Unless you want to spend real money to buy in game gold.The game has a lot of personalization. You start the game selecting characters and their classes. Each character has its own passive ability and then you assign a class. You can only have one of a class per party. Each class has 4 upgradeable abilities, some are passives like regenerate HP per turn and most are combat abilities. When you level up through experience defeating enemies, you can level up a skill. Leveling up skills increases the MP they use, so its a double edged sword where eventually you can only use a skill once or twice before you need to rest or use potions. There are items that will regenerate MP and HP along with increase maximums.The combat abilities feel useful. Paladins have a leader strike that is a powerful attack. The strike will increase their threat to enemies driving the majority of attacks to that character. To balance the attention, the paladin has a temporary shield power, a flash heal for themselves and devotion that increases the base HP. A cleric can heal the entire party or focus healing on one character. They can also use a smite skill that damages an enemy and heals themselves. To round things out there is a weakening spell to debuff enemy attack power for three enemies. Mages have a single enemy damaging fireball that will burn them, damaging HP each turn. They also have a deep freeze that damages and stuns an enemy. Mages also have a meteor that damages an entire enemy party and finally a passive stream that increases the base MP. I can't cover all the classes, but they feel well rounded. The classes have to feel well rounded, because the game is nothing but combat. A chess game between you and enemies that you chose to fight. The game has plenty of quests to give you and you can tackle them one at a time. Nothing that will stump you, since all the 'quests' seem to be collect X amount of Y or defeat X amount of Y enemies. Escort X from point A to B and then fight a battle. It wouldn't seem like such a grind if your travel had more exploration instead of moving along a line from location to location. There is some banter along the way, but its just your party sitting at a table facing a dungeon master with different beautiful backgrounds. The battles get long, even with better equipment. It gets frustrating when you complete a quest to kill 7 plants only to get another quest to kill 9 plants. Then that quest followed by another quest to get 19 carrots. How? By killing the same plants you've just slaughtered. You can always pick your quests, but its useless when you'll end up doing them all anyway.When you visit a town, you don't walk to a store, you just click on an icon that will open up the store. The items are nice. Upgrading weapons and armor involves a gambling system. Sure it costs 150 gold to have a blacksmith upgrade your gear, but there's only a 35% chance he'll succeed. Seems like a gamble and a waste of gold. The blacksmith will get better with every try . You can even increase the blacksmith's experience by using grindstones that you'll buy or find in caves.That leads me to warn you of this. Microtransactions. Why grind for gold when you can just buy it with real life money? The microtransactions aren't in your face or annoying, but they are there and some people have problems with that. If you want gold, go kill some enemies, there's nothing else to do in the game.If someone in your party dies, that costs gold. Since resurrection costs gold, when your party gets wiped out and you don't have enough gold to resurrect one of them, that's it. It was originally a gameover, because the game will save itself preventing you from going back to a previous point when your party was alive. So you'd have to buy gold with real life money. Luckily, there is now a free continue that will resurrect everyone, but reset their level experience. I'm thankful of that. If you don't want to grind to level up your characters, you can always buy experience with gold. There is always a need for gold. Whether its experience, resurrection, traveling, or gambling to upgrade your equipment. Oh and don't forget buying stuff.At some point, this game is busy work and you know some people are ok with that. In all, I would say its a fun game, but other RPGs are better. Since this is trying to be a Dungeons & Dragons simulator without being a true RPG its just lacking in some areas.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Cute concept for a game. Unfortunately, the novelty wears off fairly quickly, and the actual gameplay just doesn't hold up. Traditional jRPGs are carried by their characters and story, because the combat and mechanics thereof are so one-dimensional and stale.So Knights of Pen and Paper has the same boring combat as any Dragon Warrior/Dragon Quest/Final Fantasy/etc game, but all the writing, charm, and polish has been replaced by easy jokes about RPG tropes.If RPGs are played for the story, where's the story? I guess the gag is that there is no story, that this is the RPG stripped down and laid bare. I can buy that. But since there's no gameplay worth noting, does that joke really carry a game for 5+ hours? I don't think it does. The premise is done a hundred times better by Half Minute Hero - which has all the same lazy RPG "observational humor", but uses it as a fluffy coat to the solid framework of fun, interesting gameplay. I recommend you pick that up, instead. Knights of Pen and Paper isn't worth the time it takes to finish it, much less the asking price.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Don't let the complaints fool you. This is actually a great arcade classic turn-based RPG experience. Think of the original Final Fantasy games, in a much more fun, comedic fashion, but still has the challenge, and core elements you love. You will go on grand adventures, fighting many various foes with a pretty good storyline.There's options to increase the challenge for even greater rewards / xp, loot, etc. etc. vamping the difficulty that suits you.It's hard to explain all the qualities that makes this game so cute, and enjoyable, but I think it's definitely something every RPG fan would love to play for a few hours. The main downside people seem to complain about is that there's one very small in-game real money shop, which you can pay like $1-5 for in-game gold. The game is not balanced around this shop, and I've never once understood why it was in the game. Perhaps it's for "stupid people" who make foolish decisions, or need a "boost", but I did not need it.However, I did decide to go with the digital deluxe edition for $1 more, which comes with a lot of goodies, including a new character, 800 starting gold, some minor boosts and a new area with a monster super effective to all dmg. (fast easy xp + gold)I paid: $3.75 (digital deluxe)Reccomended price: $5

number of helpful: 16 of 21 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
 This isn't a terribly bad game, but it's fun is very fleeting and you'll forget about it the minute you exit out of it. The premise was cool and was the main reason I bought it but they really didn't do anything with it - the characters are all interchangable (literally) and the dialog seems to be aimed at kids - the humor is mostly refrencing things and changing one word or changing it slightly (Wizards of the East Coast, HAHAHAHA). You set your own pace on everything, like choosing which enemies you want to fight and how many, so the game never really suprises or challenges you. The quests are boring and all feel like sidequests (kill this many things, go here, collect this many things, blahblahblah). They've taken microtransactions out of the game but you can tell a lot of the mechanics were set up with those in mind.They do have some neat things like the ability to buy upgrades and powerups for the 'real life' players, and these upgrades carry over different saves, but there isn't enough of this and you'll have most the things you want rather early on. The graphics are pretty nice as well, if you like the 8bit style. This game is probably better played on a phone or mobile device, this isn't a terrible port but it shows it was made for a touch screen in mind - for example you have to select the enemy to attack every time. I'd recommend buying this on a mobile touch screen device, it'll prob cost less - also it'd be easier to play it in short bursts like it is prob meant to be played.In short, they botched it.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												First of all, there was an update that killed save files, which is a big problem for an RPG of this length.  I wasn't interested in replaying the first ten hours of the game, so I've never played it since then.  I'm not really sure what the developers were thinking.  It was an old game when the patch came out, so the loss of save files was definitely unexpected.Also, it's pretty dumb that if you already have some of the DLC from buying the +1 Edition, you can't just buy the extra DLC you're missing without rebuying it with the base game.  Come on now.As for the game itself, I would rate as so-so.  The theme and art is top-notch, but everything else becomes kind of a drag as you keep playing.  There's way too many boring encounters.  Some of the areas seem really poorly balanced-- I went into a dungeon with a level rating lower than my party's, and was basically insta-killed (had zero problems up to that point).  You might like it a little better than I did if you're a big fan of grindy RPGs, because there's a LOT of grinding.  What kept me playing was the witty writing, but it wasn't quite strong enough to carry the game on its own.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												A fun little twist on the typical computer RPG, where you are both the DM and the players.  It does get a bit grindy, and there's little to no storyline to speak of, but I have yet to see another RPG-like game that incorporates the meta concept at all, let alone as well as this one does.  The concept is interesting, and while combat does get repetitive and you end up doing a lot of gold-farming, the tongue-in-cheek dialogue and easter eggs help keep it interesting.This is, admittedly, the kind of game that's best played in short bursts rather than long sessions, but if you remember the days of 8-bit games and wonder what computerized D&D could have been like back then... this isn't a perfect approximation, but it's a fun little game that's worth a try, particularly if you can get it on sale.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												A great casual game. It really only has the one game mechanic, as if you're in a battle in a final fantasy game, or any turn-based RPG - Each turn you choose to battle / magic / item, and your party defeats monsters. An interesting aspect of this game is that you control the number and difficulty of most of the encounters. But graphically, there is not much beyond what you see in the trailer. Besides the world map, and the table where your party sits, you don't move around.It could get boring for some, if you're not looking for an endless battle; but the game is as difficult or as easy as you choose to make it. I definitely think it's worth it. It's very easy to pick up and play a few minutes at a time, as there's no learning curve. There are enough random encounters, and it's well polished, this game will keep me entertained for hours.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												This is a game you will love or hate depending on your tolerance for RPG tropes. The best parts are when it succesfully makes fun of the cliches of CRPG's while bringing a sense of humour about what makes the pen and paper versions so much fun. At its worst it IS those cliches. One of the things I really disliked was that to upgrade your characters standard weapons and armour costs a fortune at the blacksmith and requires extensive upgrades to get above a less than %50 chance of the upgrade being successful (Your money, which is in short suppy, is spent regardless). You can upgrade the chance by getting grindstones, but GRIND is the opperative word. Grindstones are only available in caves and there is only a precentage of getting one for each ore pile you click on. You will need to go back to these places again and again and again to try to get enough grindstones to raise the chance of an upgrade succeeding more than %50 of the time. I do like it, but with caveats. If you can tolerate the random grinding required, go for it.Pros:         Good sense of humour        Graphics have a lot of charm        Chirpy retro musicCons:         Grinding         Repetition         Rinse/repeat         Tear enducing upgrade system

content:
Posted: October 21, 2014
												Knights of Pen and Paper is a tongue-in-cheek look at table top RPGs. The characters are silly, the "microtransactions" even sillier, and the references to other video games and people in the industry is, quite frankly, horrible (but in a silly way). The entire game has your characters sitting at a table in various places such as a village, a cave, an arcade, and so on, while a DM (Dungeon Master, for those of you who are unfamiliar with pen and paper RPG terminology) guides them through their quests. The graphics are simple, but fit well with the game. The music is repetitive, but catchy. And there's loads of replay value. I definitely recommend getting this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												This game easily could have been a free-to-play-game, but once you start playing, you realize that it IS a game you can play without restrictions. The idea of a table in the middle of the screen sounded weird, but you actually don't notice it in mid-battle. This is an awesome game.    It's simple enough to just pick up and play, but you can still work out a winning strategy. Think of it like Pokemon. You can kinda ignore the stats and get through the game, but you can also maximize your team's potential by equiping certain items. So if you don't want to think about it, you can make it through, but if you do the math, you can do better. It's. Just. Awesome. You can go pretty much anywhere right from the start, but you'll probably die if you do. But that's still an option.    I recommend reading a guide before playing, as there is some terms you probably won't understand, but it's smooth sailing from there.

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												Maybe this game works well on a cellphone but to sit down and deliberately play it on a PC is laughable. The gameplay is so incredibly shallow you can win practically every encounter by closing your eyes and clicking your mouse unless you try to stack the odds against yourself (which you will since every fight is so simple) and even then your rampant clicking will only be broken up to cast a healing spell now and then. There just isn't anything to it. You can pick multiple classes for your heroes but besides the 4 different abilities they all feel like they play the same. I couldn't even explain what was going on with the gold system. Everything at the store costs 1-5 coins and monsters drop a few coins here and there...but I started with like 5000 gold for some reason. I’m not entirely sure but I feel like the game tried to balance out the absence of micro-transactions of its mobile game counterpart by dumping all the gold in the world in my pocket and calling it square.If this game has anything going for it, it’s the sprite work which is very pretty and the music is pleasant but everything is massively let down by how unstimulating the game feels. It's not a BAD game but its a pretty BLAH game

number of helpful: 24 of 43 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Despite no mention of it anywhere, this game contains microstransactions that will make the game easier. This means that on top earning money through game sales themselves, the game is continually monetised through the sale of more in game currency. It also suggests that the difficulty and the amount of mindless grinding required in the game to progress is geared toward frustrating you into getting out your wallet to buy progress with real world cash.This business model is unacceptable. If I pay money for a game I expect there to be a final transaction for me to enjoy the game as is. When I'm expected to buy my progress through the game on the other hand, under no circumstances do I want to pay money up front, especially not without being notified of these transactions. I don't want to pay a fair price for a game only to find out that I will have to invest a lot more to really enjoy it.The game itself seemed clever at times, but I soon felt forced to either grind through enemies at a boringly slow pace or fork over real cash.

number of helpful: 11 of 18 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												I bought the expansion, I beat the game. And I was very disappointed.This game pretends to be themed around pen and paper roleplaying, the type that has real choices and such, not just murdering for EXP. What did we get instead? The complete opposite of the pen and paper experience. This is another bad digital RPG that any P&P player would find boring.So reviewing it for what it really is, a lackluster generic RPG, it's STILL shamefully bad. It tries to make up it's lack of creativity with unending references. Not one of these references were really funny or clever. On top of that, nothing in this came off as original at all.If I ever had a GM make a campaign that was 100% references and forced us to battle everyone we met? I'd tell him he sucked and then leave. If this was even remotely accurate to P&P games, there'd be an option to seduce every single enemy encounter. You know? SOME choice at least to do something else!TL;DRFalse advertising. Just a really bad RPG made by a bunch of meme kids.

number of helpful: 28 of 51 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
All the 90's references can't make up for Knights of Pen and Paper's grinding, mobile roots.Pros: Graphics, Sounds, ControlsCons: Gameplay, Story, BugsFor fans of pixel graphics, Knights of Pen and Paper will not disappoint, although it may be a waste of most computers' potential.  The sounds and music fit well, although they may begin to grate after a few hours.  Control with the mouse and the smallish menus are perfect.Unfortunately, the grindy, repetitive gameplay is where Knights of Pen and Paper shows its mobile roots.  The story isn't terrible, but lacks the great moments often had whilst playing true tabletop RPGs.  For achievement hounds, the Deluxe Edition is a must, as it provides a slightly better grinding area.  A number of achievement bugs ensure that the grind lasts many hours longer than it should.Knights of Pen and Paper is a throwback game in many ways, but a number of flaws mar it severly.5/10

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												Quite enjoyable.  Perhaps the jokes are obvious as some reviews have said, but they're still fun.The game is better if your computer is a touch-screen as this is a mobile port.  Mouse clicking is kind of a drag primarily because of this reason (click the Skills button, now move the mouse up to click the thing you want to attack, now move back down to click the Skills button of the next hero, now back up to click the enemy, now back down...).  It would have been better to add some keyboard/controller support.But, speaking of the whole "mobile port" thing, it IS nice that I can transfer my save file from my Android device and play my current game on my PC and Mac.  I've gone between all three platforms without too much trouble--just save it to my choice of cloud storage and then download it into the game file folders to play from where I left off.  The fact that there isn't Steam Cloud is a bummer, but since Steam doesn't have a client on Android, it doesn't matter too much for me.Overall, very nice little game.  Grab it on sale and have some old-school fun.

content:
Posted: March 24
												Knights of Pen and Paper is a solid game, but not a perfect one. It has fairly well thought out mechanics and there is nothing you can do in the game that the game itself doesn’t make intuitive to do, but there are multiple points when the difficulty-curve is not so well designed, even going so far as to require you to grind well after finishing every quest in the game save one that is actually HARDER then the last main quest of the game.It is also very simple. In fact many would probably call this game an RPG-lite and they would not be wrong. Despite the new angle of playing the people around the table instead of the heroes on their character sheets, this game is overall a very simple title… simple enough I was not surprised to see the game is readily available, not just on the PC, but on mobile phones.This makes for a surprisingly good game overall, but not one designed to be played over long sessions. Rather, it’s a series of bite-sized sessions that will ultimately get you through the to the end, assuming you have the patients to get through some of the later muck.Full review is available at http://redsectorshutdown.blogspot.com/2017/03/knights-of-pen-and-paper-pc-review.html

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												As much as I wanted to be able to recommend this game as at least a casual mindless fun type of title, it turns out that the game is not even successful at that. The game's premise of telling a story from the point of view of people playing a Tabletop RPG is played painfully straight without any humor involved other than the premise itself. The game also provides no attempts at being an authentic Tabletop RPG experience by being restrictively linear and having a fixed storyline. Speaking of which, the game's story has no sense of atmospheric or emotional depth and is paper thin, no pun intended, and is literally the most generic and bare bones story you can think of for a fantasy game. Again no attempts are made to actually make this interesting or relate it to the game's premise. The gameplay is made up entirely of fetch quests that are normally reserved for sidequests, and there is no exploration included at all. The game will stop being fun after about an hour. Also the game features micro-transactions in the form of buying in game money with real world money, and the game's design seems to be based around making you use up as much in game money as possible. Traveling to new locations, reviving dead partners both cost in game money despite making no logical sense why this should be the case. Up grading weapons is something that costs an absurd amount of money to attempt, but it starts out with only a 35% chance of working, and the only way to increase that percentage is to successfully upgrade weapons. Because of this, you will likely go through all your in game money really quickly, and seeing as how money takes a ridiculously long time to farm in this game, it seems entirely likely that the idea was to get you to use the micro-transactions.This game is not recommended.Full Review Here http://www.gamefaqs.com/PC/708672-knights-of-pen-and-paper-1-edition/reviews/156854

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2013
												In a word: Avoid. Read on for reasons.A game that simulates pen and paper RPGs? Sounds great, doesn't it? This game will do just that, but the Dungeon Master is largely unamusing, which leads to a mundane story. The comments your party makes are usually cheesy one-liners or memes, or video game references. You roll a d20 for quests, upgrading gear, getting grindstones in caves, resting in non-towns, and travelling, and failing a dice roll only makes the game more tedious. The battle system is all turn-based, and order is loosely based on initiative, but it's mostly random.A more minor point though are the microtransactions for in-game gold which are COMPLETELY UNNECESSARY but for some reason every day some guy will complain about "ermergerd microtransactions" in the community hub. The microtransactions are NOT REQUIRED at any point in the game; the microtransactions only help you by shaving off a few minutes of your time that would otherwise have been spent doing what you already have to do for the entire game. The microtransactions only give you gold. You get gold from fighting monsters. For the obsessive, completionist players:As of typing up this post there are at least 5 broken achievements out of 43. Apparently there have been inquiries sent to the developers asking when the achievements will be fixed, and the answer provided was that the devs were busy working on another project that isn't Knights of Pen and Paper. tl;dr:Do not buy, because:1. Unoriginal plot2. Ridiculously random3. Unnecessarily tedious4. Broken achievements

number of helpful: 35 of 66 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												If you've ever played an mmo like WoW and during the quests you would often get to get x amount of y thing or kill x amount of z monsters and you thought, "Holy crap that sounds, and is, like the most fun I have ever had!" then this game is for you!It starts off grabing your interest with a prision escape and a cute art style and 'dnd' type set up, but quickly wears down into a slogging grind fest. There isn't any decisions to be made (As one would expect from a dnd game) or strategy, and there isn't even any dice rolling aside from travel or sleeping. The classes are un balanced like crazy. The mage and the cleric are easily the best classes in the game. The rogue is in 3rd at average and the warrior and paladin are just complete garbage. The characters dont do anything story wise and there is no banter or personality to them.The character sheets are pretty boring. Each character gets 3 active skills and 1 passive that you can level up. However the skills are just about asa basic and uninteresting as you can get. The mage has a fireball, Frostbolt, meteor, and mana increase skill. The Cleric has smite, heal all, heal one, and a damage debuff skill. The rogue has a stealth, double strike, disable, and posion skill. The warrior has a healing, damage debuff, cleave, and one more skill I forgot. And the paladin has a shield, heal, aggro strike, and defense increase skill. B-O-R-I-N-G!!!You do have a nice selection of buyable items to give buffs thought. Various items/props/food and even the dm can be changed. I do think that is nice and adds some charm to the game. The equipable items however, are again boring +to stat upgrades. Nothing cool or interesting.I hate not recommending this game as it is a solid concept that I hope to see expanded and improved in the future, but in its current state it just isn't worth your time or money.

Product received for free
												To preface this, I won this in a giveaway (on steamgifts)...I absolutely enjoyed this game.  I am currently going through a D&D cycle of obsession right now and this totally fit the video game need for that in a really odd way.  The game itself is fun as it totally pokes fun of all the nerdiness that is associated with table top role playing games.  It functions pretty well overall, but you can definitely power play this and not have as much enjoyment.  This leads me to believe it has a bit of a balance issue, but it doesn't really matter too much.The controls and interface are pretty straight forward, no issues at all. I didn't try to see if there were hotkeys for the characters ablities as I was just playing with my mouse mostly. Overall I would give this a 10/15.  4/5 for controls, 3/5 for gameplay, and 3/5 for graphics.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												This game is really great.The story line is funny and there's plenty of eastereggs to find.The concept of gaining gold to buy more or new party members is fun and the fact that the gold can be used for items that change the status effects in the game (the game that they play) is really neat.And the meta. This game really uses the whole meta concept so nicely, that I haven't played another game that does is quite this well.Theres plenty of replayability, since you unlock more characters as you play and there's those nice achievements to get, from playing with different charanter setups. Some of the achievements are actually quite hard to do, which just makes it more enjoyable.The game can get quite repetative and combat can drag out a little, so it becomes more of a grind than a fun experience. But for me the promise of what happens when you get to the next part of the story is enough to get me through it. It you really hate repeating the same pattern over and over again in order to win fights, then I would not recommend playing this game.This game does deliver what it promises though.8/10 since the grind does drag it down a little

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												If you're a GFX junkie, then this game certainly is not for you. Graphics and mucis are all 8bit and at first glance the game itself seems to be written in some old version of BASIC on a Comodore 64 (which is actually quite possible :D). But underneat that layer of all that 8bit gloss there's an extremely fun game!This game is full of humor and all standard old-school pen-n-paper RPG clichés that you have probably done when you actually played those pen-n-paper games with friends. Sadly though, that DM kinda sucks. If I had him for a DM in my pen-n-paper sessions, we'd have long discussions about NPC naming, story telling and such. But I think this is most likely yet an other prank from the developers :pI picked it up for €2,50 on the sale today, but if I knew this game was so much fun, I would have bought it earlier and have paid the €10 as well. It's really worth it, so much fun this game gives me!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												Now here's a charming tidbit of experimental gaming. A player pretending to be players role playing a game. It could have gone so wrong, but the developers understand that brevity is the better part of expression, and choice representations of tranditional pen and paper role playing cement this as a must play for anyone curious enough to give this a second look.It may take you that long to realize just what's happening, but once you do you'll probably be hooked ensuring your Grandma has her 17th level Paladin wearing fully upgraded equipment. The biggest drawback is the titles in game currency, which on iOS translates to real world microtransactions. Fortunately you can quest your way through earning all of the gold you'll need to pay for all of your upgrades.This is an addictive game, and the pixel art style has its appeal, through does not appear to scale well to all resolutions. A minor gripe, as the gameplay is the most compelling aspect. You'll want to grind away so your players can have the leveling high. There's no doubt this is a niche experience, but one you'll no doubt remember. A little pricey solo, I'd suggest buying the bundle of both Knights of Pen and Paper I and its sequel in one package (available via either of the games Steam pages).

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												This game pulls off imitating the tabletop experience well for good and for ill.THINGS THS IS GAME DOES LIKE TABLETOP GAMING:~Travel is quick because travel is boring.~Travel is still something that you have to do too much.~The NPCs that stand out remain well in your memory~The NPCs that don't are all exactly the same re-skinned NPC, other than MAYBE half a dozen they are all boring~The jokes remind me of the same type of self-referencial humor as expereinced with your first highschool GM~The jokes still suck.~The early game is a desperate struggle against keeping the squishies alive long enough for them to unleash the hurt on the enemies.~The late game every fight is waiting on the wizard or equivilant to denign to cast the right spell after the rest of the party spend the whole combat setting it up.~Enemies actually have some flavor to them that is easily apparent.~Enemies are universially made tougher by merit of adding hitpoints and raw damage rather than tricks or tactics.I wish the game had more elements of randomness, like miss chances based ona rolled die in combat rather than it only being effected on the map.I'm marking this as a RECOMMEND, but only buy it if you really like old school RPGs and/or tabletop gaming

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Knight of Pen & Paper is a simulator of RPG style combats. You can choose which monster to beat and how many of them. So you're totally free to put your own difficulty.The game reminds me of those old roleplays used to be "played" in forums:5 characters around a table with a master that is telling all the interactions you're doing with them. Plenty of environments, classes and monsters more or less tough are available during the quests.The bad point is the repetitive actions in combat, from a place to another you can't change your character because it will take too long to level. A character has only 4 skills, you can easily choose which skill is the best though you will note that the effects of a single skill does the same for every monster: An ice monster should be weak against fire. The mage class uses "Fireball", no effect. "Deep Freeze", super effective, and that against most of the monsters.Finally, the game should be fine for beginners, who never played any old RPG game before because Knights Of Pen & Paper is really easy to beat, hard with patience.Otherwise, I think the game would fit better on phone and tablets.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												Knights of Pen and Paper is a blast. I love turn-based RPGs and this game is an excellent one that has a solid mixture of gameplay, humor and replay value that took me by surprise. To start off with, if you enjoy turn-based RPGs then this is worth buying. Read on for a more in-depth review.In Knights of Pen and Paper you play as some friends sitting around a table and playing a Dungeons and Dragons-like game. You pick out your party and set up their class before the game begins which I thought was pretty cool. Typically new characters are introduced throughout the game, so it's interesting that we get to create our own dream team to play with. That's not all. You'll still find more characters throughout your time in the game. They'll offer new classes to use which you can switch out whenever you're not in combat. I found the cast of Knight of Pen and Paper to be nothing less than diverse and clever.The gameplay is pretty basic at far as turn-based RPGs go. Each party member and enemy will get a turn, and you're given a bar showing who's turn is when so you can plan out your turns accordingly. Leveling is a lot of fun as you get to unlock new abilities and see how each of these characters evolve. For me, the true appeal of Knights of Pen and Paper is its presentation. The story isn't groundbreaking--it's about as generic as any quest in Dungeons and Dragons could be. However, the characters themselves are entertaining as the story plays out. The developers did a great job of portraying all the party members as human beings who with personalities. Sometimes someone will question the logic of something absurd happening and is quickly told to shut up by the game master. I also remember one character being jubilant in defeating a boss and the text-based dialogue was perfect. Whenever I saw the speech bubbles appear I got a little excited.Knights of Pen and Paper is a solid game. It's got a classic feel to the gameplay, it has amazing presentation and it doesn't take itself seriously in the least. Even if you've never played a turn-based RPG, this is a game that would be the perfect entry to the genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												"Now THIS is what I call of Retro Love Letter, folks."After playing a said 15 hours throughout the game, I couldn't help but put it down with a smile.Before I begin, there are several things you should know: Knights of Pen and Paper +1 Edition isn't a perfect game. Not even close. But that being said, it is some of the most humourous, most rewarding and most awkwardly endearing RPGs I've played in a while.It's pretty much a heartfelt love letter to retro gamers and DND gamers like myself; plenty of brilliant references ("Journey" Village, anyone?), a hilariously cheesy plot, as well as there being plenty of fun things to go around.While most RPGs place you on the receiving end of the game, you both control the players AND the gamemaster; you control the characters' decisions and actions throughout the game, while you conduct any battles you choose of. Giving a total of 12 classes (I think; could be wrong) and 15 "players" to choose from, the game keeps things rather interesting with the gamers' unique quirks and diverse classes.While some complexity fans might find this a problem, the skill system isn't too deep. You generally have 1-3 something active powers wherein you have 1-3 passive powers. You upgrade it, and you get an increase of power in that skill. Personally, I found it enjoyable at the simplicity of the skill system, and wherein some hardcore gamers will probably be dissapointed, I found it organized and simple to enjoy the game.As for the story, while it's admittedly paper-thin, it's nonetheless enjoyable. You have a set of five gamers set out to save the world from rats, bandits, yetis, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles(C), Pac-Man ghosts, fire hydrants (I kinda made that one up...), and YOUR MOM! No seriously, you actually fight your mom in this game as the equivalent of Kingdom Hearts 2's Sephiroth.Then you get to the quests of the game, which isn't as fun. It's practically divided into three types: defeat "X" Y times, escort/deliver/travel x to y/to y, and find X. But even then, I found enjoyment of it for the reason I'm going to list in a bit. A common complaint with the game is that it follows the typical cliches of an 8-bit RPG and too much repetition. But even then, the game damn well KNOWS it cliched! I can count the number of lampshadings how the "hero arrives just in the nick of time", but you get the idea. And honestly: was Secrets of Mana repetitve in some areas? Yes. Was Chrono Trigger repetitive in some areas? Yes indeed. Was Final Fantasy repetitive in some areas? Yes, yes it was. And that's what made the game so enjoyable in my opinion: how it lampoons every issue with classic RPGs while providing it a loving tribute to it. Along with the create design the game offers, it's hard not to love it.The game's only downside as far as I'm concerened, is the dungeons. Not only are the to few and to far, but the randomness of it, the pure frustration of the difficulty, and the fact that it's completely out of the players' control could've made it much better. But I guess that's the price for having a focus in an other area oh so much so.In the end, if you like action-packed gameplay, deep skill systems, and fast pacing, then this game will probably not be for you. However, if you love retro gaming, memorable, if not cheesy, writing, and incredible optimization, then you will love this game as much as I did.Overall Verdict: 9/10. Superb game, really recommend it for your steam library.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												Overall this is a fun game with a few downsides.Pros:- graphics- music- references and jokes- this is a long game- character building (you can respec skills for small amount of gold)- fights are fun- game about playing a role-playing game- insane and fun plot- DLC is fair and square. It's a long, Halloween themed, series of quests.- some classes are really powerfulCons:- some classes are relatively weak- repetitive quests - that are fun nonetheless, due to amusing writing- grinding gold and XP - you really need to grind a lot of gold and XP just to advance further- upgrading weapons and armors takes too much gold- some fights take too long to finish- this game is mainly about fighting enemies- the plot develops fully only after playing like about 10 hours into the game, before that one point it's mainly a fantasy parody- you see those Space Invaders and school bullies in trailer? Good, you'll encounter them after about 10 hours of gameplay- one bad decision during buying stuff or upgrading weapons/armor can result in a need to grind more gold for about half an hourTo be honest - I've had a blast of a time with this game. It was fun, jokes were really good, the plot was absolutely insane. I can recommend playing this game if you like parody games that have focus on battles. Drop it if you don't like too much fighting and grinding gold/xp on same enemies over and over again.______For anyone interested in joining in on completing your own backlog; check it out here - http://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog/discussions/5/530645446320364338/

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Heh.-_-Okay, so: do you A.) Like Dungeons and Dragons-style adventuring games?B.) Like playing actual D&D style games, on pen and paper?C.) Would like to try a simulator of the two?This is that game. Will you like it? That's debatable.I bought this game when it was a daily deal because I like pen and paper D&D-style games. Note that I had received all of the boosts from the digital deluxe version.The retro-style graphics are a nice aesthetic, and there is quite a bit of variety with the creatures you will encounter in the game.So the game plays with you as the DM (dungeon master) overseeing a game of D20 Knights of Pen and Paper. You have seats that can sit how ever many characters you would like to use, but the last few seats require you to pay the in-game currency. You can keep grinding to afford the seats in the future.For each seat, you can sit a type of character (ex: hipster, grandma) and assign them a specific class (ex: barbarian, bard). This offers a seemingly wide range of party configurations.The difficulty is completely self-driven, as you are both the DM and the players. That being said, you may have an "objective" to kill 5 orcs - you can choose to fight them 1-at-a-time, or all at once, or whatever configuration you prefer. The entirety of the game involves A LOT of grinding, and this is even considering the boosts you may have gotten from the deluxe edition. I love D20 games, but this game can become repetitive extremely quickly. If there was a multiplayer cooperative functionality, it might have saved it a bit, however, there isn't one.There is A LOT of variety for you to upgrade - you can change everything from the type of table you're playing on (each type provides different bonuses) to the type of door in the room to the DM. All of this can help shape your overall party into a specfic area, like tanky high HP characters, or high MP, magic-relying casters.I paid ~$5 US for the deluxe edition, and I think even then you may want to hold off and wait for it to be cheaper, if you are interested in trying the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												This game is just absolutely fantastic! 20/D20I've been wanting to get involved in D&D for AGES but I just can't seem to a) Find any friends who want too b) Find any groups in my area that run a weekly or something.. A little sad.. But oh well I'll keep looking. In the meantime - This game fills that space perfectly! It's got quick wit, great humor, reflections on a vast array of older games; most of which I had a really nice time remembering thanks to this beauty!The gameplay is fairly quick and gets you into it without boring you in any way. A nice range of different classes, each one seperating it from the last meaning you can mix and match your 5-man squad quite a bit to your preferences!Difficulty can be .. Sort off.. Scaled. By choosing more enemies it makes it more difficult. I personally don't class this as 'difficulty' as such, and you can cheat the system by setting the enemies closer or further apart to suit your teams attack.. Though, even with 7 enemies sometimes it can be 'easy'.. This is a slight downside, but still isn't much of one and you won't be choosing 7 enemies to fight until you become stronger anyway, as it is generally too much (when matched against similar levels that is).But generally speaking this is a great game with tons of great moments!! If you're a fan of RPG's and D&D in general, you'll love this (I think..)!! :DPlus the new ones out soon!! Can't wait!!!

content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												Pretty brilliant. It's a turn based RPG, but it's not hard for noobies.You can balance it yourself by starting with more or less characters. I would strongly recommend starting with 5 players because the endgame is very hard otherwise.Other then that you really need to play it for an hour or two to find out if it's for you. I like the dry humor and pop culture references. And how it doesn't take itself too seriously. But some people call this 'lacking in depth' and I guess they're right too. They do re-use certain backgrounds and let you grind from level 32-37 and 1 mission later 37-45 at the end of the game, so they definitely rushed through the end trying to add some 'gameplay' without putting in work sadly. That level 50 mission is optional btw. Throughout the rest of the game there is rarely a need to grind though. Do note that the game has some large bugs. Some achievements are broken, some missions are broken, DLC doesn't work for some and there's graphical glitches. This seems like a hasty port honestly. And then there's the fact that if you want the Deluxier Edition you have to buy it at once. You can't upgrade. If you already have Normal edition or Deluxe edition (extra's, but no DLC) you're screwed. Also they just wiped everybody's saves trying to emplement the (not fully working) cloud save. Then wiped all saves again when reverting to the old build.So the game is very fun, but beware that this game is published by Paradox. As long as you're lucky enough to be in the 90% for whom most things don't break you're good. But if something goes wrong there's no support and dealing with Paradox is like talking to a 3 year old and when they realize you're right they just ignore you.I only recommend this game because it's unique. It's very money-grabby, too expensive and the publisher is unethical and clearly doesn't care about it's customers, but the game is so much  fun and most people don't care about what happens behind the scenes. And if I'd downvote it the fanboys would downvote this review and you wouldn't be reading about the downsides of this game right now.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Pros:The game is kind of humorous.The backgrounds look nice.They removed microtransactionsCons:The gameplay lacks any depth.The game is super grindy.The game is REALLY resource intensive for what it is. (It uses 14% to 17% of my CPU just idling at the title screen.)Text is recycled far too often.The music isn't bad, but it is way too short. So in a given fight it probably loops 5 or 6 times.Alternate save files don't have independant gold, room items, characters, or classes; however, the blacksmith doesn't carry over. (The whole idea of all that being persistent is just stupid as it was physically impossible to get the game over achievement unless I deleted my save file.)More of a nitpick, but the developers made themselves the best characters in the game. (That's a bit too narassistic, in my opinion, and since they have ♥♥♥♥♥♥ one-liners it ruins most of the fun of the game.)Overall:I got the game in a sale because it looked like it would fun to play. Little did I know I would just make a party full of physical attackers, leave the twister floor mat on, and just run this in the background while I played other games. The game got a bit of a chuckle from me when I first played it, but as the game dragged on it just got more monotonous due to there being no real growth in the game. Everything in the game scales linearly, including mana costs, so it's more about playing keep up with how much health the enemies in later areas have as opposed to actually feeling strong.

												For quite a few hours I really liked this game. Then I ended up with all my party dead and not enough gold to revive more than one. And not enough gold then to take that one to an area in which to earn more gold. Sooo.... heading to the internet I read up on what happened and I saw a lot of confused information about other save systems, a blacksmith that wasn't mentioned in the game from what I could see, and microtransations that may or may not be in the pc version of the game as they were in the ios version for the mobile.Really such a shame as up until then I was loving the game, but seriously not enough to try and start it all over again. It's simple enough in premise, very more-ish when you're playing but unless you know what you are doing before you start, I wouldn't bother. If you do want to play it, definitely read up on it all before you start as you'll  have zero help in game.
