content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												At first, I thought this game was great!  However, then it just turned into a grind and the completionist in me forced me to play through and finish it.  Here are the main complaints:-The game progresses pretty smoothly and you don't need to grind much until the last dungeon.  I could get to the last dungeon easily, but then had to do almost 5 levels of grinding with all my guys just to be able to complete the final dungeon.-The blacksmith levels up far too slowly. The only way to level him is to get him grindstones, which you can find 1 to 4 of in certain locations.  However, at the final level you can give him 20-30 grindstones and barely move his xp bar.-Any game that encourages micro-transactions has already failed.

number of helpful: 13 of 25 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Knights of Pen and Paper +1 Edition is an example of what is wrong with the gaming industry, publishers and developers working together to make a game that is less than a full and proper experience without first investing heavily in it.  In most cases, that means you must use real world money to make your game run the way it should in the first place.  Luckily the game gives players a choice, you have the choice to play the game a great deal, or to buy shortcuts to make the game better.  Everywhere you turn there is a price attached to everything, you can gain the currency with playing or with plastic, and playing takes way too long.I would say that the game itself, when you ignore this horrible choice of microtransactions, is mediocre, not exceptional.  It has several novel ideas, but it lacks any real pay off, there is nothing revolutionary or deeply engaging about it.  Even the flavour text, the stuff you would hope would be most entertaining in a dungeons and dragons type of game feels weak and boring, as though the developers were not into it.Overall, I was quite disappointed with this title and I don't think many people will be able to enjoy it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
												Fun concept, bad execution.  The sequel is more recommended.  There are just TONS of better indie RPGs on Steam, that are more stable and more appropriately priced.*Edit - After spending a bit more time with Knights of Pen & Paper 2, I can honestly say that it is a superior product in every way shape and form.  All of the things that were promising and intriguing about the original, just not an awful pile of badly ported mobile garbage.  Skip this game and please go buy the sequel - it's fantastic.Nothing but cons to list here:Unstable and buggy port, my game was even missing a bunch of the dialogue.Poorly written dialogue, confusing and nonsensical story.Wide array of classes and items, that are almost all entirely useless due to lack of necessity/context in which to use them, and complete inability to level alternative classes once you reach mid or end-game (beyond an incredibly long and boring grind, repeating the same fights over and over for hours on end).End-game is an equally long and boring grind, money is extremely hard to come by, since the original (mobile) version of the game encouraged you to pay cash for gold - The disparity was never fixed when porting to PC.The price is absurd.  The port is so badly done, that there is zero justification for the seven dollar price increase.  The $4.99 DLC is a slap in the face for the amount of content received.  Easily should have been a $2.99 game w/ $0.99 DLC.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												What a little gem! I found this beauty in the Paradox Humble Bundle (still available at the time of writing so go grab it if you haven't already) and fell in love with it. Not the style of RPG that I've really had much experience with so for me this was a bit of an experiment. I digress, a simple and smooth game that's easy to get into. I found it a little odd that my rogue has an attack almost double that of my warrior but that's pretty much the only issue I've had. Of course there's grinding... and then some more grinding Oh I'm sorry did you think you were done? Guess what!?MORE GRINDINGBut that's what you sign up for with these games, you have to be prepared for it and I have to say, it pays off. The parody of the traditional D&D scenario is wonderful and the humor is very self aware. The references are tasteful and abundant but not overly so that they obscure the story.I would recommend this to anyone lacking the means, friends or who's simply as antisocial as myself to actually play D&D (not a bad thing) to give this a go if you are interested in that sort of thing.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2013
												This game is awesome, well worth the low price, I also recommend the digital deluxe edition. It includes some gold and stuff, but mainly a village thats GREAT for grinding xp in the early parts of the game.Anyway, heres my thoughts:Sound: The soundtrack isn't bad, pretty much what you'd expect in an rpg game, I do occasionally get sick of the looping song. However, the boss music is awesome and intense.Graphics: The graphics rock, It's all pixel art and it looks awesome!Gameplay: The gameplay is pretty simple, but its also fun and at times, hilarious. The basic idea is your a bunch of people playing a game like dungeons and dragons in a basement. You choose your characters race (Pizza guy, jock, nerd etc) and class (cleric warrior paladin mage etc) and start playing. As you level up you will unlock and upgrade your different skills. There are plenty of fun items to find and equip, and I also joy at leveling up. Not only can you  buy ingame items, you can buy furniture, new tables, and snacks and drinks for the basement that your ACTUALLY playing the game in for buffs in the game. Pretty funny if you ask me. The game is very fun to play overall, even though at times, the missions feel a bit similar.Overall I would give this game a 8.7 out of 10.

												I quite liked Knights of Pen and Paper+1. I liked the classes, the gameplay. However In the latest patch the developers accidentally deleted all the saved games. Accidents can happen, and they promised us a "Master Save" that "should appeal to all users that had their save deleted"The Master Save however is somewhat of a joke. No XP potions, Character/class choices that are dubious at best, a rediculously low amount of gold and not nerely enough unlocks. What they really should have given us was a lot of Gold, XP potions and grindstones so we could remake our party as we had before.The first was an honest mistake, the latter was simply insulting.

YouTube™ Video: Steam Cleaning - Knights of Pen and Paper +1 Edition

			Built upon the 'game within a game' concept, the player creates players who play the game while they play the game of managing the players.		

Built upon the 'game within a game' concept, the player creates players who play the game while they play the game of managing the players.Many classic tabletop RPG tropes are highlighted here with awkward adventures, illogical random encounters and McGuffins as far as the eye can see.  Having been ported from mobile devices the pacing and flow of the game still has some of the feel from the original versions which can drag the experience down.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												This game is a wonderful mini-masterpiece that makes you feel as if you're playing a table-top game without the actual table or friends. You can experience D&D-style gameplay without having to break out dice, charts, pencils, and painted figures, and it really makes it much easier to immerse yourself into the game. With the deluxe edition, you get SO many awesome new items and references to play with, including furniture such as THE TARDIS from Doctor Who, 800 gold coins and starting buff items, and even a new player character that makes a powerful magic user! I'd honestly buy the game just for that.So many different players-class combinations to choose from that could either make the game difficult or easy, and it's so much fun to try different combos!I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes RPG games, humor, and gaming/television references!

content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
												It's a charming concept that loses its charm fairly quickly. The humor gets old, and the combat system gets boring and repetitive. The story is pretty bland and its execution is poor, drowned in the midst of required jobber battles that the game throws at you in a mockery of typical poor DMing style. It's got the American Nightmare problem in which it acknowledges why what it's parodying is lame, but doesn't actually do anything to fix it. Something that's ironically bad is still, unfortunately, bad.In all, it feels like a quirky, above-average quickie mobile game that sells itself as an engaging RPG.If you like that sort of thing, then get it when it's on sale. It's not worth $10.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												I don't know where and when I got this game...But... This game...This game is awesome!I liked the overall parody feel about it while it has a strong and solid work about delivering action and plot in moderation, getting some loud laughs from me here and there. The battle is unforgiving, so you always have to be focused, despite it being turn-based. The difficulty is adjustable in a manner "How frisky you are today?", taking on anything between 1 and 7 rats or elite monsters. The open-ended way the characters are presented lets you use your imagination. I do feel like playing a table top sheets'n'pens while playing this. Yes, the feel of every character is an illusion, but it's a very-VERY well made illusion.Another point is the building difficulty: Items give you stats that you barely see. Levels give you damage that you barely see. Hp and Mana regen is earned by tears and sweat dripping down your inner thigh. All this while enemy shamelessly uses lifesteal and applies crazy bleeding stacks. Some battles will be so tight that you will stain your undergarments a bit and still lose because of the enemy randomly preferring your rouge to your fully buffed granny paladin. You will put a sleep on a DoT'ed enemy and lose your healer because of that, and you will spend 4 times the money you earned in that battle to revive your team. You will even spend 2k on upgrading your sword and still get nothing in return because you are a looser and you will have no money to leave the god forsaken town.But... You know... That's what's good about this game... That's what's your adventure is. And you should not just accept it, but have tons of fun while at it!I would like to say thank you to the developers. I've seen a lot of attempts to do what they achieved in this game and i think they did it better than anyone else I've seen so far, including UnEpic and Magicka, the first being too far away and the second being a bit too silly. But this game, oh, this game grabs the bull by his modesty and makes him enjoy it so much that he's ashamed afterwards, but he begs for more.Highly recommend.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												I wanted to like this game, I really did. It had a nice aesthetic, nice music, and it was from a small studio. Had I been aware that this was an iOS app before it was a PC game, I might've been more wary. The first couple hours went by relatively nicely, but after that, not so much. If you buy the Deluxe Edition DLC, you get the Magika Wizard, a character with a better passive skill advantage than most other (see next point) characters. Around level 15, you unlock the Developer Player Characters, self-inserts that have even better passives, making whatever current party you're using seem feeble in comparison. Also around this time, you'll notice your strength isn't getting you as far as it did in the beginning, so you go to buy gear. Only, the blacksmith, by default, has a 30-some percent chance at actually crafting the item you pay him for. So, either you toss bags of money at the him, praying that he succeeds (because of course he doesn't reimburse you), or you get grindstones, items that let you "level him up". It takes around 2000 grindstones at 25 gold apiece to have him reach 100%. That's 50,000 gold. At level 15, you might gain 200 per fight. Oh, but what's this? You can buy gold in-game for real money! Of course you can. Sadly, this game really was designed as a cash-hungry iOS game first and foremost. 4/10, for the initial hour or two of fun before the grind.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												This little game, a nostalgic blend of retro-console RPG's and old-school D&D, is novel and amusing. I love the interface, with the DM seated on one side of a table and the players (characters) on the other side, and with the scenery changing around them and the ranks of opponents springing up from behind the DM's shoulders. Character development and turn-based combat are simplistic and two-dimensional, but interesting and challenging. However, it all starts to get repetitive and a little monotonous after a half-dozen or so hours of play. If you can get this game on sale for under $5, it's worthwhile. As for the in-game gold that can be bought with real-world money: It's totally unnecessary, and buying some may even spoil the game for you, since it will make the game too easy and reduce the number of enjoyable hours you'll get out of it.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												I feel torn about this game.  At first it was interesting in the simplicity and style, yet as the game progresses it feel immensely tedious.  There will be quests where you are required to go from one location to another and have to fight at each step along the way, sometimes up to five or six battles.  Then once you arrive the quest is to slay a number of monsters repeatedly.  The endgame seems almost unfair, requiring a lot of grinding unless you spend a lot of time exploring sidequests.  Based on the price, I think the game has a niche in the category of game where you advance through it periodically while taking a break from other games.  Could improvements be made? Absolutely, but for an indie title with some creative 4th wall shattering, it serves it's place decently.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												What a little gem! I found this beauty in the Paradox Humble Bundle (still available at the time of writing so go grab it if you haven't already) and fell in love with it. Not the style of RPG that I've really had much experience with so for me this was a bit of an experiment. I digress, a simple and smooth game that's easy to get into. I found it a little odd that my rogue has an attack almost double that of my warrior but that's pretty much the only issue I've had. Of course there's grinding... and then some more grinding Oh I'm sorry did you think you were done? Guess what!?MORE GRINDINGBut that's what you sign up for with these games, you have to be prepared for it and I have to say, it pays off. The parody of the traditional D&D scenario is wonderful and the humor is very self aware. The references are tasteful and abundant but not overly so that they obscure the story.I would recommend this to anyone lacking the means, friends or who's simply as antisocial as myself to actually play D&D (not a bad thing) to give this a go if you are interested in that sort of thing.

												I love how easy this game is to pick up and put down (though putting it down is harder and harder the more I get into it!). I love the idea of the game with the players at the table as the main UI etc.I too have been thoroughly enjoying the game and it's a shame those MicroTransaction (MT) haters can't see past their own hate of MTs to give this game a go. The MTs are such a non-issue, the game is not gimped in any way, shape or form without using the MTs. All I can say is, give the game a go.. you will genuine like it if you like old school rpgs.One of the most enjoyable turn based RPGs I've played for a while.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												An absolutely ridiculous game, the good kind.I find references here more often than I do in World of Warcraft, it's insane, I mean the starting "Master", is the fat Comic Store guy from The Simpsons, and another of the starting "Bonus objects", is a Tardis.Even if you go to a certain place, you find the top of a Stargate, it's horrifically funny in my opinion.On a more serious note, the gameplay itself is more simple than it may seem, sure it's tactical, being a WoW veteran, I had to go for a "Tank, healer, dps and offtank/dps" kinda thing, with a Paladin tank, Warrior offtank and Druid healer, obviously later on I added a Rogue and a Hunter for dps, but you can do any combination possible.All-in-all, simple, funny, and easy game, I'm going to let you decide on the rest.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Firstly I will tell you this game is a mobile port.Second it has a microtransaction of buying ingame gold for cash,but you never  and I mean never need to use it.There are plenty of items ingame that increase the amount of gold you get dropped that have other stats to them.Now to the review.Short Review:Game has classes you can swap in and out,skills that you can level individually,upgradeable class locked weapons/armor and plenty of item accessories and consumables.The game has pop culture reference comedy all throughout it,hardly any variation in quest types and is grindy since you only turn-base fight your way through each situation for the most part.Plenty of boss fights in the game,no puzzles, and a small learning curve on how to handle things. Uses dice roll to determine things such as crafting chance,battles,etc. If you like games you can play 5min-1hr + at a time,do not mind grind , a pop culture heavy comedic story, and little varation in gameplay then pick it up on sale, or in a bundle. I would not pay full price,just does not feel like a $10 game , more like a $2.50-$5 one.Regular Review:The game itself is a comedic sort of table top dice roll turned into a video game.The dialog trees,characters, and the story have comedy all throughout them. The game has tons of pop culture references from 1970s- onward in both enemies,outfits and dialog.Gameplay mechanic wise you pretty much fight turn based fight your way through all the quests you do.There is hardly any variation in the quests escort,item fetch/deliever,rescue, and fight/slay. They incorporate you grind fighting your way through.There are no puzzles or anything so do not expect much outsite of witty dialog and fights.Items in the game are what you would expect, consumables with stat buffs that last for a certain time.Weapons/armor are not sold but are upgraded by blacksmiths.They are only found in towns as well as item purchases.There are different character classes each with 4 skills that you can level up individually.When you decide what character classes you want you have to pick a person whom hs their on special stat they add to be that class.You can swap in and out character classes that you level up when you are at towns with taverns.The game can be played for 5min- 1hr+ depending on how much grinding and story you are willing to play through. There is a NG+ when you beat the game to continue on your adventures which resets all the quests making the mobs tougher at the beginning onward.My final verdict on this game is if you do not mind the grind,it is a enjoyable title.Its simple yet to the point.I played it in spurts and had fun playing it.Its deffinately not for everyone but no game out there is.Get it on sale or in a bundle, not worth $10 to me more like $2.50-$5 game.Not for lack of content,more for lack of variations in quests and gameplay mechanics.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2013
												Do not ever buy this game, even if you see it for a really low price. This game is a total bore fest that has some good concepts but overall fails at executing them. Full of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ humor, lame wannabe retro graphics, irritatingly horrible music and lame game-play that will make you wonder why you are playing this game to begin with. If you want a good Computer RPG that is similar in vein to PnP RPGs, I suggest picking up the original Fallout games or the Black Isle Studio DnD games, such as Baldur's Gate and PlaneScape. Or you could go get a legit PnP RPG game, gather your pals and play that, and that's also heaps better than this.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												I love how easy this game is to pick up and put down (though putting it down is harder and harder the more I get into it!). I love casual games of this kind, especially ones that are deep enough to really get into. I love the idea of the game with the players at the table as the main UI etc.I too have been thoroughly enjoying the game and it's a shame those MicroTransaction (MT) haters can't see past their own hate of MTs to give this game a go. The MTs are such a non-issue, the game is not gimped in any way, shape or form without using the MTs. All I can say is, give the game a go.. you will genuine like it if you like old school rpgs.One of the most enjoyable turn based RPGs I've played for a while.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												An absolutely ridiculous game, the good kind.I find references here more often than I do in World of Warcraft, it's insane, I mean the starting "Master", is the fat Comic Store guy from The Simpsons, and another of the starting "Bonus objects", is a Tardis.Even if you go to a certain place, you find the top of a Stargate, it's horrifically funny in my opinion.On a more serious note, the gameplay itself is more simple than it may seem, sure it's tactical, being a WoW veteran, I had to go for a "Tank, healer, dps and offtank/dps" kinda thing, with a Paladin tank, Warrior offtank and Druid healer, obviously later on I added a Rogue and a Hunter for dps, but you can do any combination possible.All-in-all, simple, funny, and easy game, I'm going to let you decide on the rest.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Despite being sprites rather than 3D, this game threatened to overheat my laptop, which I count the first strike against it. It's no good sacrificing graphics quality if you're still going to demand huge amounts of GPU investment. The second strike is that the massive amounts of heat are going to waste doing nothing at high speeds - the game is irritatingly slow at times, and I used CheatEngine to double KPP+1's speed to get it to a tolerable level. In-app purchases are the third strike leading me to conclude: KPP+1 is a bad game. Cute characters, witty humor, and a whole lot of hack'n'slash against evil monsters doesn't make up for poor underlying design.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												I wish there was a "meh" button between yes and no, but Knights of Pen and Paper is... well, a basic, bare-bones turn-based grindy RPG.  Don't interpret the no vote to mean I think it's a bad game, it's just not that inspiring.  You set up a party, choose which fights you want so as to make sure you don't bite off more than you can chew, and then grind, grind, and grind some more.  Then you curb-stomp a quest boss when you can be bothered.  You have four skills per character, and basically pick one or two to min-max, and use basically exclusively for the entire length of the game.  Since your potential actions are so limited in combat, the differences between one fight and the next are negligible... if you're even fighting different enemies at all, since uneven challenge and reward schedules tend to reward players heavily for fighting the same pack of creatures in droves until you're ready to leapfrog half a dozen levels to the next cash cow.  A special "rug" for auto-battling basically means this game becomes something to press "start" on, then come back to later to reset another battle.  The only real thing to do outside of battles is to buy things, so there isn't much to break the monotony.Kinghts of Pen and Paper is a decent concept, but it just doesn't engage the player enough for me to give this a good recommendation.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												First game I've ever bought on Steam where I've not actually gotten what I paid for. Sure sometimes a game will have bugs, and sometimes there may be un-noticed system requirements/limitations which are my fault for missing. But here, it's not even the right product. Advertised as win/mac/linux, but buying the deluxe version, none of that extra content shows up for linux. No response from the publisher/devs on their own steam forum linux-specific discussion. First time I've ever felt truly cheated on Steam.Edit: Dec 12th, 2014WIth the latest update, it seems that at long last 2 1/2 months later, the Deluxe Version finally works under linux. Of course they've still been selling for Linux this whole time instead of taking that off until it was fixed. What miniscule communication there has been in that time was all of poor quality and incorrect. Moreover this actual fix wasn't even described or announced. Still cannot recommend.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												Knights of Pen and Paper +1 wasn't really the game I was expecting to go through. I thought it was actually worse than it is, and I'm glad I ended up buying this title and playing through it's 9 hour-ish campaign. The basic premise is, you are a group of friends that are playing the much known fantasy tabletop role-playing game, and your adventures are depicted both through pixelated landscapes/characters and from what the D&D players are actually saying, or actually the dungeon master. Much like in the main idea from the movie Inception, you are playing a game in which the characters are playing a game. So, gameception?KoP&P (Knights of Pen and Paper) is an RPG, and most features you expect from one are available in this title. Leveling up your characters, giving them new items, armor and weapons, upgrading your character's abilities, questing your way through until the very end, or until New Game +, in which your able to replay the whole game, with the same characters, but everything is harder. It didn't really attract me, since the main campaign features a bit of grinding and I didn't want to go through the same. It's useful for completing the achievements, though.Soundtrack fits the theme of KoP&P, but can actually become boring after a few hours of gameplay. Another interesting feature is the abundance of references to tv shows, movies, etc. You eventually find a character named Nabe Gewell, which lives in Steam Island, which I found amusing. The 4th wall is also broken lots of times.In conclusion, do yourself a favor, and purchase KoP&P. It entertained me for a couple hours and I'm sure it will do the same for you. Alas, if you actually don't enjoy D&D's concept, steer in the way of another game.

												Let me first say that Its cute. Its user friendly. It has some funny moments.Having said that, I feel this game is empty. I can handle slow paced and repetitive games but Knights of Pen and Paper is so slow, so repetitive, and so monotonous that I can't appreciate it even as a background distraction while multitasking. 												The premise of the game might be funny at first, but dulls down to pure boredom as you progress through this repetetive grind fest of an RPG...The Leveling as well as the Fight mechanics are, well boring, as well as the whole presentation of the game, you just see your group of people sitting at the table doing next to nothing as you read text boxes...I know this is all intended but still, the narration just lacks the humour or tension or just anything to make up for all the downsides... I played for 10h, I had fun for 1 at most...the other 9 were just hope it could get better, but ah well, it did not...I would not recommend this game to anyone. Seriously, do not buy it, its repetetive poorly presentated garbage.

												This beings back so many great memories of playing the original table top Dungeons and Dragons. I have only put in a few hours but for being an old school gamer, this game is what I was hoping it would be, fun and attention grabbing. You start out with 2 characters and you start doing quest, mostly by killing mosters, which you gain XP and coins. With the coins you can unlock more characters, buy equipment, pay for travel, buy additional tables, buy bonuses, etc. If you are bored easy, do not like 8-bit graphics, never played D&D, or do not want to grind out some levels, then this game might not be for you.Pros: -Adjustable screen resolution-Like you are playing a D&D game-ReplayableCons:-Music (8-bit music but mute works great)-Grindy

Posted: December 6, 2014
												Cute game, but needlessly difficult.  My game functionally ended when enough of my party died that I couldn't reliably fight and didn't have enough cash to resurrect anyone.  Could I have farmed for the money in low level fights?  Yes.  Was that prospect enjoyable?  Not in the least.I do enjoy that while the game has some pretty standard stereotypes of gamers, it also embraces women, jocks, and businessmen, amongst others, at the table.  All the geek culture shout-outs were amusing.Still, any game I can't finish isn't a game I'm going to recommend.

												This game was developed with a mobile market in mind, and it shows. While the jabs at RPG norms are humorous and appreciated, the rest of this game is a shallow time waster that would be more enjoyable on the crapper or in the check out line at a grocery store. Oh yeah, and there are microtransactions, though they aren't invasive. If the meta humor alone is enough for you to part with 10 bucks, go for it. Posted: April 18, 2015
Boring.Knights of Pen & Paper is long, dull, grindy and most of all it is boring.It starts out novel enough. You are playing a game about a bunch of gamers playing D&DA few obvious jokes and references and things start out pretty well.The sound, music, graphics, they all lend themselves pretty well. But the grind, jeez! This is a single player game! Who thought that...Converted mobile app with a cash shop in the mobile version? OooooooooooooooohI don't need to say much more really. As far as converted mobile games go its actually really well ported. But the play time is so artifically padded that you probably will not complete the game. A sequel has been announced and I hope and pray it addresses the flaws this game has or even just does away with the excessive grinding for the inevitable PC port.I know some smartass will reply that this is an RPG and you are supposed to grind but this isn't 1997 anymore. Games like Bravely Default, like Magic Fantasy Battle 4, have come along and said 'listen, there is grinding but we streamlined it or we made it fun.'I stopped caring about the storyline the 8th time I was told to backtrack for excuse reasons. I especially stopped caring when my Lv32 Barbarian, with maxed equipment, wearing 4 +9attack items, still can't one shot a friggen spider! I especially was agitated that a newer version of this game was released that I can't simply upgrade too, or even buy apprently since steam says 'you already own that game' when clearly I don't. Flaws aside the game is enjoyable in short bursts which is fitting given its mobile phone roots. It was ported to the PC and no real effort was made to make it a more PC friendly game. Instead its dull, repetitive and boring.Also the achievement, beat in 365 (game)days, is unachievable it seems. That's always nice for the achievement hunters.Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												(This is a copy-paste of my Google Play review, since I apparently don't "own" a license to the app and my review was automatically deleted right after posting it) - I purchased it via the Humble Bundle.This game is a great game! In fact, I got hooked into it to the point I play it instead of Clash of Clans (if I'm not already playing Geometry Dash).It's so satisfying to be able to have a Dungeons-and-Dragons-like game in my pocket that I can bring anywhere and play at anytime.The mechanics aren't groundbreaking, but it's included everything that I've forgotten to consider as a Dungeon Master.The story's full of references to our gaming culture, but towards the end of the game, I felt that the story died after the "you have to save the world" bit... And the grind to the higher levels seemed impossible.(I mean come on... I've finished all the quests elsewhere and all my characters are only Level 37, despite having to beat Level 50-60 bosses which naturally one-shot them all, and getting gold becomes impossible without having to repeat near-death dungeons as farming lower down becomes more and more redundant as you level up since the bosses are the only thing that actually yields descent (more than 40) gold.)The only other problem with this game is (only applies to the Android version)... I can't buy the DLC or add gold.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Quite an addicting little game. Tne story involves a group of good ol' table-top rpg players trying to define the thin line that separates the game fro reality. It is a turn-based RPG where you choose what kind of adventurers you want in your group and level their character sheets as you would in a traditional table-top RPG, with dice rolls and everything. The story is the main selling point of the game and it does have its' own little charm to it, I did laugh at most of the jokes, though some of them fall a bit flat (it is mostly reference-based humour). There's a lot of text to go through, so it is not recommended for people who like to skip most of the dialogue in games. Good for playing if you have a bit of time on your hands, however I would not recommend it for "hardcore" players - they might be disappointed with the combat system (which is a bit simplistic and does not involve a lot of management) and find the game too repetitive. The progress does feel rewarding, however, there is quite a high level of grinding involved which should be taken into consideration. The art style and character design match the tone of the game well and the simple animation feels natural. The music could be better, after some time it can get a bit repetitive.Overall - I do like the game and I do recommend it if you are just looking for a little time waster.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												This game seems like a cross between an app game and a classic jrpg. Which is not a bad thing. Not a ton of skills, but combat is relatively satisfying. Graphics are weak but if you like classic console games you'll feel at home. As you play you unlock additional classes, though unfortunately those classes start at level 1, which makes playing with them frustrating. Grinding is a requirement unfortunately. Sometimes random quests unlock more meaningful quests, and everything has interesting dialog, so that's cool. The story is pretty good, the idea of playing a game about playing a game is well done.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												SO GOOD. If you play D&D, if you play RPGs, and are not averse to casual-tier play, this is an excellent pick,The class/race combinations allow some basic entry-level optimizing, as does skill advancement. The loot pool is doesn't really have strong variety; there's a few weak over-specialized items and a few strong general stats-on-stats items. But, the storyline is entertaining in a quirky way as is the dialog. There isn't a lot of grinding, you can level quickly via the quest line if you play well. I consider KoPnP+1 one of the safest bets for your money.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Surprisingly addictive.  A very original idea--playing both the game master and the players of a pen-and-paper RPG within the context of a computer game--that actually works very very well.  The graphics are retro but appealing, as is the music.  The story does not take itself seriously at all, but this is a good thing, as it makes for some very fun casual gameplay and a lot more content and play time than I expected.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Tabletop rping gone meta. This game is chock full of little gags, from visual ones in the background to quotes and characters. The gameplay itself is solid and is a lot of fun. There are times where you do have to grind but that's standard issue for an rpg and if you dislike that then there are very few rpg's I would or could recommend.I have no issues with this game... With one exception, the in game microtransactions. You can avoid them quite easily, but it irks me that it is still included in a game I had to pay for in the first place. Either be free and have microtransactions or paid and not have them not paid and have them, that's just underhanded. That being said it's actually really easy to get around. If your main team dies just create a new one and any coins they earn will be shared between the different playthroughs. There's also a new game + mode but it doesn't really add anything except the monsters being more difficult.I would highly recommend this game but I would also wait for it to appear in a steam sale.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												I really, really, really want to recommend this game. It's a cool little game and a bit addictive to boot. Had I written this review after just an hour then it would have been an enthusiastic yes! However, it has a serious flaw; it is so repetitive in nature that eventually you'll find yourself playing for the sake of it. I skip dialogs. I auto-click through tedious battles. I just want the game to be completed. My desire to achieve that has, well, almost been depleted. I made a few errors on my first go at the game. The thought of restarting fills me full of dread. There's no way I could grind my way through the game again and have any fun doing so.The game seems to lack keyboard controls, and all the mouse movement is RSI inducing. I'm sure its better on a touchscreen, but this is a review of the PC version. The developers really should look into enabling some keyboard controls.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												This game is so addictive!!!  I've played it for hours and it's always fun to just load it up whenever you have some spare minutes! :)  It's turn based combat with different classes that you can choose to add to your team and the ingame store has plenty of cool things to buy with ingame cash that you earn from battles.  It's easy enough to keep wanting another go but difficult enough to keep you trying to "just get past that next load of monsters" :)  And at this price... a must buy for any fantasy turn based combat player.  P.S. don't get put off by the pixelised low res graphics... the amount of fun and humour more than makes up for any cosmetic looks and will keep you coming back to it again and again! :)

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Knights of Pen and Paper +1, is... Different.Something you should know:On the google play store, it is only £1.99.On steam it is £7.99. For the SAME GAME.Just for this, I wouldn't reccommend buying it from Steam on principle, as even though it is a brillian game, it is still only a mobile android app. On PC.Now I got this game with a Humble Bundle, so assuming I paid the £1.99 for it, I can certainly say it was worth it.I think my first runthrough took approx 12 hours, that wasn't rushed but it wasn't lazed either, so even if you where to pay £7.99, it still has more play time then most £40 hit title campaigns.In the game you take control of 5 people role playing in a board RPG pretty much, and without going into to much detail, it's like playing a game of Dungeons & Dragons with amusing characters and dungeonmaster.The missions are reasonably simple, and if you complete the entire campaign in a day, like me, then it does get somewhat repetitive by the end, though if you actually have a life and pace it out a bit more, you may not find this the same.The game is FULL of references, there are pointers to Star Wars, Pokemon, Sponge Bob Square Pants, TMNT, Final Fantasy, Mario and much much more, almost every five minutes I would see something and be amazed at how many references they have fit in there.That is everything, and if you are reading this and the Humble Bundle PC & Android Bundle 9 is still on (It is until 14/04/14) then go and get it, as it is worth it.

Posted: June 27, 2013
												It's not a bad little game.  It's a port/adaptation of a game originally developed for smart devices, but it plays quite well in translation. There are a few small design changes I'd have made differently, and it's not as funny as I had expected, but it's a neat turn-based RPG done simply with a couple cool extras that provide some depth and customization. My overall impression after about ten hours would be a solid 8/10.  I don't feel the need to seek out a RL game of D&D afer playing this, but at least I can dork out over a D20 in secret thanks to Knights of Pen and Paper.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												KPP+1 seems like an interesting concept, but it's really not. The theme is you actually roleplay players in a roleplaying world as characters.  You get the impression this is going to result in lots of humor and a diversity of environments where the players goof around in-character, but it doesn't happen.  Instead, you just end up picking a party of characters, optimize their performance with player personalities, buy add-ons for your gameroom that give character bonuses such as a better table or door, and meander through a roleplaying world which has little plot in itself nevermind the lack of out-of-character plot among the players.  There isn't THAT much grinding if you do all the quests and use your items and gameroom bonuses appropriately to multiply the amount of experience and gold you get from battles, but you still have to complete slayer quests which are like how in MMOs you have to kill so many monsters for a reward.  The battle system is rather repetitive too.  Basically, you just get a taunting tank, heal it, and disable opponents while bombarding them with a magic dps and melee dps.  This goes on over and over with no change in tactics.  I say this despite how you can "choose the difficulty" by picking how many monsters you want to fight.  It's either you pick too little monsters to bother, pick just enough to repeat over and over, or pick too many to handle.  On the plus side, you can grab revive items in the shop in case your party dies out rather than paying the revive cost if you pick too many to handle, but it still doesn't make up for the repetition.  This is compounded by the ridiculous investment needed to level up the blacksmith by buying "grindstones".  Each one costs 25 coins, yet the optimal levels of upgrading require around 100 grindstones.  Basically, that means you have to earn 6-7k coins, and when you're earning around 50-100 coins per fight until about 75% of the way through the game where you start earning 250-300 coins per fight, that means you're not going to experience using the blacksmith for a very long time.  You also need to buy enough luck amulets and great molten rings to make the optimal level cost effective, and you have to buy gameroom items to accelerate your income, so that's another 2-3k.  This ignores how you're spending coins on other things, so it really takes a long time just to unlock better equipment for your party.The campaign ultimately feels like a tutorial sampler of what the game has to offer.  Had the game included a custom campaign editor, this would be awesome since players could make their own material and share it in the community.  Heck, the campaign even feels like it'll unlock this towards the end in saying how the gameworld is much bigger than what you can see, but it never gets unlocked.  Also, the new classes you unlock are mostly pointless.  They're effective, but you have to level them up instead of being able to introduce them into the game right away, and that's a huge timesink.  Even if you play "New Game+" you still have to level them up.  This really stinks since it'd be nice to immediately jump into using a barbarian, knight, shaman, bard, and necromancer instead of a warrior, cleric, druid, mage, and rogue.  The game however just says, "NO.  YOU DO HARD WAY OR NOT AT ALL!  GRRR!"On the other hand, if you start a plain old new game for the party, then you have to go through the hassle of upgrading the blacksmith all over again!  Don't forget the great molten rings or luck amulets too!  To be fair, you don't have to buy the income earning gameroom upgrades again, and you can technically grind out the income with your previous party in your other game since coins pool from all saved games, but still, you're talking about a good 8-9k in coins just to upgrade the blacksmith again. At that rate, you might as well just buy experience potions for 100 coins a pop to give everyone 6500 experience, plus you can buy the potion upgrades in the game room and use Ronaldo for the potion upgrade......but still, it's just more repetition.  This is supposed to be a roleplaying game instead of a railroad shooter.If the devs just spend a little more time on writing a plot, this game could have been awesome, but they didn't, so it flopped.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												KoPP is modeled after D&D gameplay. You play as a group of roleplayers sitting around a table, going on an adventure led by a dungeon master. No, really. The DM is actually there, narrating the quest. It’s a really unique RPG in its presentation, though not so much in its gameplay, which is a rather simple turn-based battle system.The simplicity owes to the game's origins on mobile platforms, and this is why recommending KoPP is complicated for me: It still plays exactly like a mobile game, much better suited for playing in small intervals. Understandably, a lot of people don't expect that from a $10 PC game. If it was the same price as the mobile version ($3), maybe it could get away with its lack of depth. Not for this price.It's also worth noting that there are microtransactions in the game. [Update: Not anymore. As of patch 2.09 (2014/02/14), they have been removed from the game.]. Also, some achievements are broken, and won't be fixed for a while. [Update: Also fixed in patch 2.09, I was able to obtain all of them.]You may be wondering why I recommend the game after all. Very simple. I still enjoyed it. I'd play it while watching a stream or something, when I wanted to unwind and avoid ultra-complex games. In a way, I went through it with the mobile mindset, and this is the case in which I'd recommend KoPP, if you want a simple game.Just don't get it for full price, even if you really want it. It's not worth it. Wait for a sale of at least 50% off.

												Fantastic game; totally worth buy at the discount. Its basically a parody d&d 8/16bit game. Develop a party of up to 5, with a few different classes (pally, druid, rogue, mage, cleric, warrior), each with their own abilities, grind enemies, or do quests. Kill enemies, get gold/loot to buy better gear. Upgrade your gear at the blacksmith. Lots of replay value imho. It may get grindy for certain buffs, but battles can be made easier or harder and you can always rest to recoup health/mana.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												(this review mainly looks at microtransactions)I initially was really excited about this game, as I find the premise and art style quite appealing. The problem lies, as many reviewers prior to me noticed, within built-in microtransactions. Ability to bypass the grind paying for in-game currency ruins any kind of trust in the economy at all. Some people might be OK with this, but I do have a couple points of contention: - The financial aspect introduces a bias from the point of developer, conscious or otherwise, to balance a game in a way that will push a player to use microtransactions. From that point on, hitting a wall, you can never possibly know either you are bad at game or the game is rigged. - Basically what a player pays for is something that earlier would've been archived by using CheatEngine or similar software. I want to stress that my point here is not "paying for something that could be free", but rather introducing the idea of cheating from the get-go. On top of that paying to not play game is plain weird to me. A bonus point - Steam page for the game doesn't have any mention of in-app purchases (aside from user reviews). With those points in mind, the choice comes down to whether you are willing to invest time into something that shouldn't be trusted by design.

												Looking for a game that you can pick up or leave on the fly? Then this is it. think of it as an actual pen and paper game like Dungeons and Dragons. then sprinkle in the NES Final Fantasy graphics and battle system and there you go you have this game.The battles are pretty quick, and you can save in the middle of things making it nice to come back to. I definitly suggest getting the +1 edition  since it offers a few extras that you can not get  on the  normal version.

												If you like turn-based fantasy combat and have nostalgia for tabletop RPGs, this just might be the game for you!Gameplay can be a bit repetitive, so it's not really a game you can sit and play for six hours, but but half an hour here, two hours there? number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Having never played the classic tabletop D&D myself, I at first find the concept interesting however this turns up becoming a disappointment. The enjoyment value in this game is pretty inadequate.1) Clicking fiestaYou basically just need to click when you want to do almost anything. Just click the shop icon to buy item, just click the map button to travel, etc. You have control of the dungeon master. You get to choose what and how many enemies you want to fight with the limit of 7 (after unlocking it) same type of creature (combination is not possible). The combat system is pretty much lacking, and no brainer. There are only three damage type, physical, nature and magic. It doesn't matter if you hit enemies with ice or fire. The only option you have in organizing your party is pretty much who you want to include in the party (max. 5), no formation whatsoever. The "threat level" system is at best vague and unclear. 2) Unclear storyline and boring questAfter playing this game for so long, I still have no idea what the story is about. Comments from the "players" range from boring to cheezy at best. The variations of sidequest are too little. Collect certain item from certain monster drop, kill certain amount of certain monster, escort someone (and 100% encounter at every place when you do this quest) and go to certain dungeon to fight with the developer. There ain't a puzzle for me to solve.3) Character creationCharacter creation is pretty much simple. Every "player" have his own bonus and you might want to make use of this bonus for the most fitting job. Each have 4 skills and set stats built. Everytime you level up, you have one skill point to spent. At first this seems okayish but as your level goes up, balance issue will be a slap on the face. Physical attack easily overpower magic skill. Leaving spellcasters as useless ragdoll.4) Bad economy and MicrotransactionThe main argument in the forum dwell on this "innocent" button on the top right corner. You can buy in game gold that you can earn by slaying monsters with real money. Why the heck it is there in a paid content anyway? Let me skip that annoyingly long argument. There are a few things that make people upset with the economy of the game. Firstly, the blacksmith. The only way to have better equipment is to go to the blacksmith (that can be found in some places) and have them upgraded for a fee. This process involve probabilistic element with success rate proportional with the level of the blacksmith. There are ways to reduce the cost and leveling the blacksmith without risking your gold but those are pretty much grinding. Secondly, you "buy" "players" with gold to start the game. There are "players" that are so expensive that it is impossible to start the game with without buying gold (on your first run). Thirdly, the gold is tied to your account, meaning that after your first run, you can start a second run with that amount that is left. This make second run pretty much broken as you probably have too much gold.5) The music is bad and annoying. It is getting on my nerves after a while.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Do you like Dungeons and Dragons? Do you like turn-based RPGs? Pixel-art? Yes?This is your game.This is a great D&D style RPG without the faux real-time of Baldur's Gate and Dragon Age: OriginsIt is a very simple game, but thats what makes it so easy to pick up in play.Not to mention that you can also controll the Dungeon Master(Narrator) which makes the game more or less challenging depending on your play style. (Although fighting low-level enemies gives you low-level rewards)The game also has a very nice Pixel-art style that is not only beautiful to look at but nice to play through. The music is also one of the best parts of the game, with a pixelated style that reminds me of old-school western RPG with a battle theme as addictive as that of any Final Fantasy game.Overall this is probably the most genuine fun I've had with an RPG in a long time, and easily one of my best finds/purchases.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												I host Dungeons & Dragons campaigns often, and this game is wonderfully similar to the kind of excitement and experience both on the end of the DM and on the end of the player. I love how the difficulty of the game scales, as you are both the game player and in a way the creator! If you think the quest is too hard, you can lower the monster count. If it's too easy, max out the  bar and fight 7 goblin warchiefs at once! Quite a fun game and hours of RPG content, worth every cent.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												(this review mainly looks at microtransactions)I initially was really excited about this game, as I find the premise and art style quite appealing. The problem lies, as many reviewers prior to me noticed, within built-in microtransactions. Ability to bypass the grind paying for in-game currency ruins any kind of trust in the economy at all. Some people might be OK with this, but I do have a couple points of contention: - The financial aspect introduces a bias from the point of developer, conscious or otherwise, to balance a game in a way that will push a player to use microtransactions. From that point on, hitting a wall, you can never possibly know either you are bad at game or the game is rigged. - Basically what a player pays for is something that earlier would've been archived by using CheatEngine or similar software. I want to stress that my point here is not "paying for something that could be free", but rather introducing the idea of cheating from the get-go. On top of that paying to not play game is plain weird to me. A bonus point - Steam page for the game doesn't have any mention of in-app purchases (aside from user reviews). With those points in mind, the choice comes down to whether you are willing to invest time into something that shouldn't be trusted by design.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												A lot of people are saying that this game is nothing more than a bad iOS port complete with microtransactions. I'm here to set the record straight: this game is an iOS port and it has microtransactions, but it's far from terrible. If anything, this game is an intimately-crafted love letter to all things nerdy (D&D, sci fi, etc.). The game does have microtransactions but, if you play it right, you don't need to buy anything beyond the game itself. The only other things that I've spent money on are trading cards (which is par for the course on Steam). If you're looking for a decent roleplaying game with hours of replay value then this is the right one for you. If the thought of microtransactions or performing repeated tasks doesn't appeal to you, then you should probably skip this game (and roleplaying games in general).

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Looking for a game that you can pick up or leave on the fly? Then this is it. think of it as an actual pen and paper game like Dungeons and Dragons. then sprinkle in the NES Final Fantasy graphics and battle system and there you go you have this game.The battles are pretty quick, and you can save in the middle of things making it nice to come back to.  Nice features to the game are the power ups you can purchase for your room that offer bonuses to your team, like extra gold when you defeat foes or extra Xp (the power ups are like pictures on the wall or snacks on the table).  I also liked that the game size was pretty small  around 100mb, which means I can leave it on my computer  for when I want a quick game.  I definitly suggest getting the +1 edition  since it offers a few extras that you can not get  on the  normal version.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Knights of Pen and Paper +1, is... Different.Something you should know:On the google play store, it is only £1.99.On steam it is £7.99. For the SAME GAME.Just for this, I wouldn't reccommend buying it from Steam on principle, as even though it is a brillian game, it is still only a mobile android app. On PC.Now I got this game with a Humble Bundle, so assuming I paid the £1.99 for it, I can certainly say it was worth it.I think my first runthrough took approx 12 hours, that wasn't rushed but it wasn't lazed either, so even if you where to pay £7.99, it still has more play time then most £40 hit title campaigns.In the game you take control of 5 people role playing in a board RPG pretty much, and without going into to much detail, it's like playing a game of Dungeons & Dragons with amusing characters and dungeonmaster.The missions are reasonably simple, and if you complete the entire campaign in a day, like me, then it does get somewhat repetitive by the end, though if you actually have a life and pace it out a bit more, you may not find this the same.The game is FULL of references, there are pointers to Star Wars, Pokemon, Sponge Bob Square Pants, TMNT, Final Fantasy, Mario and much much more, almost every five minutes I would see something and be amazed at how many references they have fit in there.That is everything, and if you are reading this and the Humble Bundle PC & Android Bundle 9 is still on (It is until 14/04/14) then go and get it, as it is worth it.

												The idea is BRILLIANT in my opinion! Here is a game clearly dedicated to pen and paper RP-ers, and the meta-feel of it all is excellent. The execution, however, is not up to par. The game begins well, with quips to geek culture all over the place. However, it quickly devolves into a "hit monsters, get XP" run of the mill game. The RP component is not there, they fail to pull jokes consistently and you get an old-school hack-and-slash RPG with a meta LOOK. The game caught my interest in the beginning, yet ended up being too boring to complete.

content:

												So I just bought this game and I've only few hours in it but I LOVE IT SO MUCH. Where to start? I guess one of the big things about this game is that you can have so much fun with it even if you play on a 2003 toaster. The soundtrack is enjoyable and immersive with MANY different tunes for creepy caves, happy villages and dangerous roads etc. The turn based gameplay is easy to get a grip of and you'll be having fun within minutes. Hilarious character choices. Oh and the game is often funny as hell. Cheek and banter flies across the game table while your party roams the land. Definitely recommend. Worth the price.... by far

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Look... if you have this game, was most likely part of a bundle. But I wouldn't have bought it otherwise. The game was supposed to be retro and amusing but turned into a horrible grind. A really *grindy* grind. It was cute for a while but then quickly got annoying... and the pop-culture references have been done to death.The quests often were "Kill 7 of X then come back" or "Collect 7-12 drops from Y then come back" and there were a few examples where you had do it that 4 times in a row. You have to pay gold to walk between locations, so it feels like you're questing on a Monopoly board; "Go south 2, kill 7, come back" or "Escort 5 spaces East, get attacked every step, come back" while you are paying each way. Dumb.The little dungeon system... is annoying. You can't rest or run away from a fight or it boots you out and you have to do the whole dungeon again. You have to wander around to find the key for the boss fight, taking damage from fights or traps 75% of the time. Who does that? Who is going to spend time to do 10-50 of those for the achievement? Pass. Just pass.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												FIRST OF ALL: the last update deleted my savegame file, so I would recommend to everyone: make backups of your saves, because the updates can reset them. Or turn off the updates for this game only.This game is fun, has a nice gameplay, unlockable cool characters, lot of achievements, and you need work with your team and use the most useful tables, decorations for you. I was on the end of the game almost, but the update just deleted my save files, so I've got one from the forum, which almost the same like mine was. There are a lot of main and sidequests, you need to upgrade the blacksmith to increase your armor and weapon stats, you can use accessories to get bonuses on your characters and you can switch to another ones and create new ones anytime within the game.About the serial number, you'll get: You can redeem it on the official Paradox forum, and CAN'T use it in-game as a promo code.The only wrong thing about this game is the update system, but the game itself is really fun and enjoyable. :)

content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												FIRST OF ALL: the last update deleted my savegame file, so I would recommend to everyone: make backups of your saves, because the updates can reset them. Or turn off the updates for this game only.This game is fun, has a nice gameplay, unlockable cool characters, lot of achievements, and you need work with your team and use the most useful tables, decorations for you. I was on the end of the game almost, but the update just deleted my save files, so I've got one from the forum, which almost the same like mine was. There are a lot of main and sidequests, you need to upgrade the blacksmith to increase your armor and weapon stats, you can use accessories to get bonuses on your characters and you can switch to another ones and create new ones anytime within the game.About the serial number, you'll get: You can redeem it on the official Paradox forum, and CAN'T use it in-game as a promo code.The only wrong thing about this game is the update system, but the game itself is really fun and enjoyable. :)

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Knights of Pen. And Paper! I tried to be witty there.Now, I'm not one to do really large reviews, but I can tell you this: Buy this game.A ton of people will go on and on about how it sucks, how it's stupid, but it's a really fun RPG game for those that are into the genre. And a lot of people have gone on to say that it's just a time waster, but no, it's more than that. Like an RPG game, it'll take you into the story the best it can. It's up to you, if you let it do it's job or not.And as such, this took me to believe that not many people gave it that starting chance. The chance to change their lives forever.Now, you might be thinking I'm biased, and yeah, I am. I never got the chance to grow up with great games that were released on older gen consoles. Like the NES, the SNES, and even the Sega Mega Drive. I got to miss the truly astonishing ups and lows of gaming history. All because I'm a kid. So, when a game like this comes along, a game that does so well at giving the player a feel of the old world, I take it like it's a van full of candy.But, TL;DR: Buy this game if you're into the genre, you won't regret it.

Posted: March 7, 2015
												A simple game that carefully balances some of the best and irreplacable facets of gaming both modern and retro. This game offers a really nice blend of modern humour and references in the form of turn-based Retro Pixel-art, all of which is set in a world set inside a game of dungeons and dragons-or-some-similar-RPG. If you have played DnD you'll get a couple of references that might tickle you greatly but its not a pre-requisite to have fun with this little gem. Great bang for your buck, good looking, nice sounding and entertaining. But I wont tell you anymore incase I ruin the magical adventure :D

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												It was fun for like 2-3 hours, then becomes very repetitive.This game did very well at mimicking the tabletop RPG feeling. With the pixel art style and humors in story it brings you back to 80's when you sit with friends and roll some dice. Gameplay is quite casual and easy to pick up when you've got some time to kill.You can create a 5 members party, every member only have 4 skills, (some of them are passive skills) and there's no positioning. So there's really not much space for tactics, you'd probably be using the same way against all types of enemies. You can create a new member and exchange someone in your party to have some variety. But trying to level  up that guy is another long way to go. There are only limited amount of quests to do, after completing them all you can do is battle with some EXP/gold efficient monsters again and again.I stopped playing when find myself stuck at a boss and have to farm some money. To me, Knights of Pen and Paper = RPG in a nutshell. It shows me what I like and dislike in RPGs, without having all those fancy graphics, cut scenes, complex battle systems, large amounts of items. And I actually like this style, if you let me pick a game to play between Knights of Pen and Paper and Final Fantasy INSERT YOUR FAVORITE NUMBER, I'd probably still choose this one.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												I love this game.  Everything about it has an old-school feel that blends tabletop RPGs with NES graphics.  There is a lot of grinding in this game, but that's what RPGs are about.  You choose your initial characters from an assortment of people who each have their own unique bonuses, then pick a class for them based on those bonuses and what you want in your party.  If you make challenging enough fights, they require a bit of strategy.  My paladin typically casts a shield to reduce damage by 50%, then increases his threat to draw attention, while my rogue stuns people for 3 turns (thanks to items I have that extend the time by 2 turns).  My mage will either AoE the entire group or fireball for a burning DoT.  My cleric has a powerful single heal, decent group heal, an offensive move called smite, and a debuff on 3 enemy's attack strength.  My newest addition, the berserker, goes berserk (I can't choose his targets but he gains extra damage and regen) and has passives/equipment that boost his crit rate above 30% while also allowing him to heal for 63% of his total damage.  And those are just my 5 classes, there's quite a few more to unlock as you play.The grinding part comes in two forms.  You'll find yourself moving back and forth to caves often to get grindstones to upgrade your blacksmith.  You'll also want to fight a lot, and grind quests to earn gold.  Gold can be spent buying yourself some equipment at the blacksmith, or on a whole bunch of upgrades to the room you play in, the table you play on, etc.  Purchases made will give your party bonuses, such as higher RNG die rolls, more gold/exp, boosted stats, regen, etc.There's always something to do in this game.  It can be tedious at times, but the humor of the game, including comments from the game master and party members help to ease this.  Overall, I think it would be a worthy addition to anyone's library who is a fan of old school RPGs.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												I love this game, it's witty, can be fun if you enjoy the grind, is fun once you've bought enough boosting items. This game has a lot of 80's kid focused humor.It's loaded with great nostalgia/references and beautifully done pixel art, the sound is great though you will likely turn the music off after 3-5 hours of playing.You can have several parties going at once and share earned gold across parties which can make for interesting progression styles. There are permenant upgrades to your table and the room you're playing from that really change the way the game is played and I felt that was a very nice touch.The DEV team was bought out so there's no real support for the game anymore, it has some odd bugs in it still and can occasionally break if you do some things too quickly.Overall 100%ing this game was fun and a steady challenge it took me just under 30 hours.I have a difficult time recommending this game though since it's not really something that just anyone can pick up and play. This game can be frustratingly difficult at times. Especially if your party composition is unable to overcome an obstacle, you may have to start a new game to support your main party.But I've decided to recommend it due to the 8bit charm it has throughout the game which is really entertaining.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												I had a ton of fun with this classic arcade style turn-based RPG. There's plenty to love in designing your own D&D room, then using all the bonuses in the game world when you start playing. I can see this used to be a "pay-to-win" sort of game, but thankfully that's been taken out so it's all good now.As far as style and identity, this game has NONE of it's own. Every creature, every location, virtually every screen and character and bit of dialogue is pulled from somewhere else. The temples are marked with nintendo controllers. Gonzo and Rizzo (muppets) are aliens. There are Chozo (metriod) statues and dancing skeletons and everything in between. This game is a giant cluster-(blank) of references, both of the pop-culture and video game history variety. While this IS charming, it does get old after a while. There's a difference between a cute little nod towards another game, and just building your ENTIRE GAME around references.TDLR:+It's very, very fun and cute for a quick laugh. (excellent price)+It's a solid turn-based RPG that'll tickle your nostalgia bone.+20-25hr campaign with tons of unlockables.+/-The ENTIRE GAME is nothing but references to other games and geek culture.+/- Low difficulty, okay replay value.-Some achievements are needlessly grindy. (Complete 50 dungeons, wee!)-Some achievements are badly bugged. 1-3 of them simply don't work or don't work as intended.Is it worth getting? If you're ingrained in nerd culture and can grasp all the nintendo, Doctor Who and other references-- its more than worth it's price tag. Check it out. :)

BRASIL POHA!!+ Boa variedade de inimigos.+ Cenários interessantes.+ MUITAS referências.+ Conquistas fáceis.Contras:- Quando se cria uma classe e aplica este a um personagem, caso você queira mudar de personagem, não tem como recuperar os pontos de habilidade da classe, ou seja, você terá que upar tudo novamente.- Possui uma conquista muito CHATA: finalizar calabouço 50x (desnecessário).- Não possui nuvem steam, MAS você pode se cadastrar in game no sistema da desenvolvedora e assim manter os seus saves.Conclusão:* O jogo passa um excelente e nostalgico clima retrô com seu layout pixelado.* Quem possui amigos com seus mais de 27 anos de idade relembrará dos momentos de RPG de mesa graças as conversas entre os personagens e as referências espalhadas não apenas pelo ambiente mais também pelos próprios personagens.* VALE MUITO COMPRAR ESSE JOGO!================================ E N G L I S H ================================This game is so funny!!!!I played for 50h, and I didn't notice the time going by. It's a true RPG Simulator.Pros:+ Brazilian developers. BRAZIL RULES!!!+ Good variation of enemies.+ Interesting scenarios.+ It has too many references.+ Easy achievements.Cons:- When you create a class and apply this to a some character, if you want change the character, you'll not be able to recover the skill points from this class, in other words, you'll have to up the skill points again.- The game has a ANNOYING achievement: Finish a Dungeon 50x (unnecessary ¬¬').- It doesn't have Steam Cloud, BUT you can create an account in game on the developers's system and then keep secure your progress.Conclusion:* The game shows an excellent and nostalgic retro climate with your pixelated layout.* Who have many friends with more or less 27 years old will remember the moments when you played RPG board game. All this thanks the conversation between the characters, the references scattered on the scenarios and the character types too.* Well BUY FAST THIS GAME!

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Knights of Pen and Paper is what I'd call a sufficiently flawed dungeon-crawler.  While the game does allow for a lot of "customization", the upgrade system feels wholly dissapointing.  Upgrades/level-ups are barely even noticable, being slight precentage upgrades that almost always mean next to nothing; The variation of the classes is really where the enjoyment of the customization is.  In addition to the lackluster upgrade system, the entire game is grind-ey as all hell.  Want to upgrade your armor? be prepared to either walk back-and-forth between town and cave for a couple hours; that or pay through the nose with your hard-earned gold.  The humor/references are cute at times, but get old very fast... with neither making up for the repetitive gameplay.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
												Really bad port. You can't use the keyboard. It is all just clicking. Nothing is different from the mobile version. It is the same exact game. You are not getting anything more in the PC version. Even the quests are the same. I'd really recommend the mobile version to play on the go, the PC version has nothing more to offer. It's like bringing Angry Birds to PC, it's just the same game, it's not worth more.Now if they expanded on the game and made it more PC friendly, able to use a keyboard, and made the UI fit better on the screen, it would have been a great game. But it's not. The only difference is that you click instead of touch.Now I like the game on mobile, but this is just a bad PC port. It's still a good RPG overall though, I really like it.

Posted: September 3, 2016
												Interesting idea: you play as pen-and-paper roleplayers, using every stereotype a bad GM can throw at you: cringeworthy story, funny-sounding remarks and lots of combat. If this sounds bad, you either have not played a pen-and-paper RPG, or you were lucky enough to have exceptional GMs. :)If the game could be completed in 5-8 hours, I would recommend it as great and funny satire. However, it is very padded out: at 14 hours, I was close to finish it (I guess), but should have to level up characters or grind for more equipment, and I said, enough is enough.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												This concept sounds good on paper; classic D&D how you remember playing classic D&D. Unfortunately, they left out the game part of D&D.Essentially, this game is trying to be a humorous game. It's not one you play for a challenge or for fun, but to laugh at. Unfortunately, there are only so many jokes, and there's lots of battling that must be done to go forward. Typically, you'll spend at least ten minutes battling before the next joke or reference, and there's still no guarantee you'll even find it funny.That might be acceptable if battling was any fun, but unfortunately, it isn't. Every enemy in the game (at least those that I saw) does the exact same thing: Attack on their turn. There is literally nothing to react to except damage. To make matters worse, once you reach level 5 and unlock each of your skills, you can kiss any sense of progression goodbye, since every subsequent level only grants more stat-ups and numerical upgrades to said skills. As for loot and gear, the fun is sucked out of that too; while loot often drops, you have access to a store that sells pretty much any gear you could ever need, so if you're halfway intelligent about visiting it, any loot that drops will always be inferior vendor trash.Lastly, the game is OBSCENELY grindy. This is the level of grind I would expect from an poorly-made free MMO. Doing almost anything in the game costs coins; often a lot of them. And there are two ways to get coins: A) Win battles, or B) Buy them with real money.
