number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												Knights of Pen and Paper is quirky, it's enjoyable, and charming, but what's really down there is a game that's downright infuriating. The actual concept of a fun D&D like experience of Knights of Pen and Paper sounds fun and gives it a nice charm to it, but it's simply put down by extremely simple and boring battle mechanics, proceding to follow by annoying dice rolls that become much more of an annoyance then an actual Tabletop game, extreme grinding to the point of just annoyance, and the fact that this game isn't simply something to play a long session on just doesn't give it a justifiable pricetag that's way too expensive for it's own good. It works as a fun mobile game, and I really love the charm and such, but it's still isn't enough to warrant such a purchase of 10 dollars.I don't know, maybe I am judging it a bit too much, after all, it's roots were from a mobile game. I wouldn't recommend playing this game to many people (Particularly those who don't like mobile games and their microtransaction-like models), but if you like something that can be played in short bursts, is quirky, and simple, this game is for you.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												This is one of those games you might give a quick look and pass on, but you'd be making a grave mistake!If you're into oldschool style turn-based RPGs, pick up KoPP+1.  It's a ton of fun and completely playable in both short doses and long sessions, with a decent story that pokes a lot of fun at the entire table-top RPG genre and many other pop icons.  I purchased it on a whim and quickly fell in love with the quaint graphics, the quirky story, and the RPG style character/equipment progression. With the amount of time I've sunk into the game (replaying and achievement hunting), I'm forced to give the game a 9/10 rating and highly recommend it!  I wish there were more games like it!

												I just bought this as part of a package deal for $5.09.  It came with a promo code, but it is impossible to enter it in game.  The game doesn't let you use lowercase letters even though the code has them.  Consequently, it won't accept the promo code.  Finding an error in programing within the first minute of playing the game and hearing the grinding, iritating, and monotonous music looping over and over again as frustration builds soured my opinion instantly.  Ever stop watching a movie within the first minute of playing it?  That can happen with video games too.  There are plenty of reviews about gameplay, but the community needs to know about flaws as well to get an accurate picture.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												This is not the best looking game, but it is a fun RPG to play.  I run it in a window while I do other things on my PC.The game is a very simple, single player, turn-based, RPG game, where a bunch of friends sit at a table with a DM and play a D&D-type game by a rolling a die to decide everything (view trailer on Steam).  You can have anywhere from 2-5 people in your group.  The graphics are Pixel Art (i.e. very basic square pixels to create everything).  There is a simple map with locations that are level based.  You have a main quest line as well as additional quests per location.  Finishing some quests can open up new quests throughout the map.  There are also dungeons, that have their own maps, monsters, bosses, etc..There are 12 player types and 17 character types, although not all of the player/character types are available initially.  Each player and character can only be used once in your group.  Each player type, gives your character a passive skill.  Each character type, has 4 skills that can be a mix of passive/active skills.  You get a skill point each time you level your character.  There are quests to find the additional player/character types and once they are found they are available to all save slots (see below).The game has three save slots, so you can have three different groups playing the game.  The game only has one pool of gold that is shared between all three save slots.  You can purchase new tables, table items, room accouterments, doors, walls, and other items that will also be shared between all save slots.  So once they are purchased, they are available to all three player groups.  A couple of essential items are the BK Crown and the Holy Grail, which allow you to face 7 enemies at a time (default 5) and have 5 party members (default 3?).  You get bonus XP for larger groups of enemies.  You earn gold at the end of each fight, quest, etc..  You use gold to purchase potions and items from a store/blacksmith/enchanter/etc..  You also need gold to travel.  You can fight at any location to generate some gold as needed.  You can rest after most fights to recoup your health/mana, although a dice will roll to see if you have any interruptions to your sleep.  If your player dies, you can revive them but paying gold.  Initially, your low level character can be resurrected for 0 gold.  I played the game without needing any potions by just using my group's healing and mana generators during a fight or resting after a fight.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												As an avid fan of the D20 system and DnD series(I play Ver. 3.5 currently) created my the Great and Powerful Melevolence himself, Gary Gygax, I loved the pitch off the bat! It's in retro 8-bit animation style, leaving room for extra nostalgia for those who used to play the old DnD Game Boy games and NES games(amongst other titles too!). The story(campaign) is funny, edgy, tense and just an all around perfect adventure. The aspects that I enjoy most from this game is Armor and Weapons upgrading through the Blacksmith(which you can upgrade with donations of materials, etc.) and that you CHOOSE how big of a fight you get yourself and your party into. It's like having a voyeur POV of a very long DnD campaign, and YOU CONTROL IT! What's not to like?! :3

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												I wasn't expecting to like this game as much as I have been. In all honesty, this is a fun little game! There's several different kinds of combinations you can make with your characters, and there's also new classes to unlock along the way, which just adds to the replayability to see all the different kinds of combinations. The gameplay is incredibly simple, but it's fun to kind of 'multitask' as you're doing something in the background while also playing this game in windowed mode.The game also kind of lets you 'choose' how the game progresses, as you're essentially the Dungeon Master. You can choose what kind of enemy to fight, and also how many of them. This allows for you to play at your own pace!You can also add on more characters as you go along (up to five in total), but you'd have to level them up all the way from level one, which can be kind of a pain, but, ya know, comes with the territory. The same applies for whenever you unlock a class and want to use them. You'd have to level them up from level one. Kind of sucks, but once again, this is supposed to be reminiscent of old-school RPG's. You want to play that new class you just unlocked? Gotta start 'em from the beginning.Overall, even though I'm only a few hours into the game, I still want to play it and progress even further. This game could definitely keep you occupied for a while, especially if you're looking for a more traditional, old-school RPG. Check it out!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												This is one that I’d been playing on and off alongside Grand Theft Auto 5. You’ve gotta understand, GTA5 is addictive enough that pretty much everything else fell by the wayside, so that’s really saying something. Knights is a really fun game that’s about…well, gaming. Specifically, it parodies tabletop RPGs, dungeon masters, and so on.You get to form a party of up to five people with varying classes such as fighter, paladin, and so on…but with real people such as little brother, jock, nerd, and so on. The combination of the two forces kind of creates a whole new class in most cases, fully capable of being stronger within their respective classes or at the very least more interesting.In fact, you can change everything including the toys on the table, back pieces, dungeon master himself, and so on in order to modify various bonuses, buffs, and the like. I’ve never played that much into tabletop, but this game is nothing but addictive and it’s easy to see why. If you like RPGs or in general you’re looking for something easy to pick up and play, this one’s for you.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												This game is awful. I got it in a bundle. It plays like Dragon Warrior (the ultimate example of why JRPGs are bad) but with microtransactions. The whole "real people playing a pnp RPG" concept is paper thin. It just gives you additional stats that directly update your combat abilities (e.g. buy a new gaming table and get +1 to attack) and stuff like that. The microtransaction angle is really heavily pushed on the player.It's a pure progress quest. Choose to churn through monster type "A" until they drop enough coins to afford the sword that can kill monster type "B." These developers should be boycotted for all of eternity. I'm really disappointed in Paradox for publishing it too. This has to be the most shallow, unethically money grubbing game they've ever put their name on. I can't imagine their cut of the sales would compensate them for being associated with this trash.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												It only took 30+ years for someone to make an RPG game about D&D, from the third person perspective.I can't stress enough how much I love this game. It's just so unique and lovable. The dialogue is great and the amount of things you can do in the game are ridiculous. One thing I love is that the game rewards you for pushing yourself to the limit. The harder you make it on yourself, the more EXP and Gold you'll earn, making the game easier overall, later down the line. But give yourself an easy time and the game will become brutal at the later stages. There are multiple classes (Some are secret. Shhhh...) to choose from and multiple players for those characters. For example, the Hipster playing as a Druid or your Grandma playing as a Necromancer. Make your own party and formulate your own way to win. Anything is possible. Single target DOT team. An AoE team. 'Classic' 1 tank, 3 DPS and a healer. Whatever you want to do.There are microtransactions apparent in the game, but they are about as pointless as a chocolate radiator. Best not to bother with them. In fact, just forget I said anything at all.Like classic RPG's? Buy it. Have some fun. 10/10.

												I really enjoyed playing this game. I got kind of hooked on it while I was playing from my laptop (which has the gpu that can just about handle rendering a webpage) and I ended up playing for 4h straight. It's got a lot of classic RPG elements in it, which I like very much. There is talk of a lot of humor, but I did not see too much of that (yet?). The functionality is nice, and it's great that you can switch between characters during a game. Only thing I find lacking is pokémon style upgrading abilities for the spells.Also, it would have been nice to have the game full screen and a little more animation on the player characters. All in all a very good choice to waste a couple of hours on.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												It was cute and clever and all. Fun for the first ten levels.And then everything gets grindy. Like, really grindy.There are, maybe 6, 7 classes all with 4 skills each (some are randomly passive, too). So it turns into a lot of grinding and not enough variety. Which might be good for them because they used to have microtransactions for gold. They might still have that option on the mobile version, too.There was also confusion because Steam will give you an acess code and tell you that the program will possibly need it. On the main menu of the game you will also see an option for inputting such a code. However, no matter how many times you try, the code Steam gives you is not the code needed to unlock the game, the game is activated upon perchase. What you are supposed to use with the code Steam gives you is registering for the game dev/publishers' website forms...ops. And the option to input a key is extra content that was given out during an event. So...yeah...thanks for the absence of an explaination, guys.So all in all, Good on the art, good on the humor, not so good on the gameplay.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Good fun for the price; >>>but buyer beware!!<<<I got this on Friday and have played the hell out of it this weekend.  Super addictive little RPG game that has a great angle with the way you are people playing a D&D campaign.  Love the retro graphics and all the homages to pop-culture. Worth $3.00 for the +1 version? Absolutely.Here is the caveat; this game is broken and has been since June 2013.  Developers are to busy making a new game to fix the unattainable Steam Achievements for KOPAP+1 so if you like/don't mind having a half empty achievements list this is the game for you.  Personally I was♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ they should remove achievements from the list if they just don't work in the current version of the game.  Also there is some sloppy dialouge skipping. When I played this I always felt that no matter what classes I chose that the combat was still on the simple side.  This game will never be able to shake the feeling that you're playing a micro-transaction based iPhone/Andriod game because that is what it is, just now on Steam.  There are a total of 3 interesting dungeons but the reward for running them isn't nearly where it should be.All in all it's a great time killer and for the price you can't go wrong.  Maybe one tday they'll patch the issues but after 6 months of knowing about it and doing nothing don't hold your breath.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												I picked this game for the concept alone.  A game about characters playing a tabletop RPG.  While the premise sounds promising, it doesn't exactly follow that format which would have turned this game into a sim of sorts.  What it does present is an amusing Turn Based RPG game of the old days, from classics like Dragon Warrior to D&D.As someone who actually played D&D for a few years, this game was rather appealing.  Select your team of generic players and their class (and will wear a matching hat for said class) and start an adventure.  The game provides you what most RPG games tend to have: a sense of direction.  You're provided with the main storyline and a few side-quests to pick up some extra gold and exp.Be warned, this game has micro-transactions.  It is not a vital aspect of the game as you can earn gold by farming but it's only optional.  I personally do not approve of it but that should not stop other people from doing so.  Your money.If you are looking for a charming, turn-based RPG that is a bit out of the ordinary, check this title out.  I'm enjoying it so far.

												A game that obliterates your grasp of time.  This game should not be initiated late in the evening as you will almost always find yourself still playing by one in the morning.  New players begin with five seats, but can only afford to fill two of them at first.  Choose carefully which skills your heroes will specialize in, don't make jack-of-all-trades; because even though you can 'usually' controll the strength of the mob parties you will fight, you can't afford to be unspecialized.   I'm loving this game so much I can barely elequate.Humor:  Casual, but usually satisfactory, 8-bit cliches and DM wit, 7/10Music: Fits the game, it's 8-bit rpg themes, what is there to say?  6/10Controls: Smoothe as giant moth fur.  In combat, whoevers turn it is, no need to click 'attack' and then select which enemy to attack, just click the enemy and, wham, a virtual 'rush' mechanic for mopping up weaker mobs.  The world map could've been given a bit more compensation room at the fringes because you click and drag the map to move it around and some locations ARE right at the edges, just a minor irritation there, could've been fixed with the ability to zoom out, but they didn't include that.  There were other things, but overall, deserves a 9/10Visuals: In an 8-bit tabletop rpg sim, all you can ask for is a great color pallete, and it's in there.  8/10This game is virtually always in Ironman mode, constantly autosaving, so even if you hit esc enough times to terminate the game, no need to freak for your progress' sake :)That's enough from me, enjoy, my comerade gamers, *drops the mic*

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Between Steam and the Android version, I've surely logged 40 or 50 hours on this game. It's great fun, and the game-within-a-game structure makes for some funny moments in the main quest. While the gameplay can get a little stale after you've maxed everyone out (not hard to do), it's still a fun diversion from time to time. I can wholeheartedly recommend KoP&P, but at the same time ... it's game that's also a tremendous missed opportunity for something greater.My big complaint about the game is the lack of additional content. The one DLC, "Haunted Fall," is a mere sliver of addtional content, and hardly worth the price. This is the kind of game that SCREAMS for a rich set of adds ons and expansions, particularly for high-level gameplay. After two years, however, we have one lackluster, overpriced expansion that would have been a free upgrade from most other publishers.If it had Steam Workshop support, it could easily become one of the best pick-up-and-play RPG games out there. But, again, we have nothing like that. Just a great core game and some tantatlizingly untapped potential.That said, at $10 it's a touch on the pricey side. I picked my copy up on sale for perhaps $5, and when the DLC was maybe $3. It's a great deal at $8, but I'm not sure I'd feel the same way at $20 for the Deluxier version. If you can get it on steep sale, you won't regret it. Otherwise, stick to the much cheaper mobile version,

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Knights of Pen and Paper +1 Edition is a turn based RPG game set in a scenario that is a, well, table top pen and paper game, the game starts out with you choosing two starting party members from a specific selection of characters and classes, for example, a jock and a warrior, each character having their own little passive buffs, such as the Jock having a +1 to attack.Whilst the concept is nice, the gameplay tried and true, and characters, classes, and enemies all nicely diverse, and the quests a bit repetetive, you might begin to become a bit tired of doing the typical selection of escort, kill set number of enemies, or rescue quests, that is, only if you're not a fan of games such as this.Overall, the game is a fun one, with a humorous setting and story, I highly reccomend it if you're a fan of turn based RPGs, or RPGs in general, and even more so if you enjoy humorous games.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Knights of Pen and Paper is like a online board game/dungeons and dragons game.The game isn't exactly like a dungeons and dragons game but is a RPG/Adventure and action filled game. With different characters to chose from the adventure is different.I found that this game is very fun, has some old school memories involved and has comedy and cool missions to go on.Each character has different abilities and weaponry, but also each character has a special characteristic which makes then unique.Such as the Cleric which is the healer can also be built as a damage person as well as healing.The amazing use of customizing the background of the game has some different passive abilities which change how the game is played.The layout equipment has cool abilities such as small xp boosts in battle and also a higher pickup chance.The battles are cool as well, the customizing of how many enemies you face is a great way to lower the difficulty if a new character is introduced to the party. This makes the game much harder or easier for the player, for a smooth ride or for a hardcore bombardment of Giant Rats or Bats.Kinghts of Pen and Paper is simple, enjoyable, addictive and has a unique feel to it.The game is worth the buy and has many enjoyable features which i may not have discovered yet. Deffs buy the game and try it out9/10 Good Game. GG.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
Grade: 96/100Difficulty: Easy.Pros: If you've ever played a tabletop game, this is a walk in the park. The humor and references make it fun to play. The variety of options adds a lot of depth to the game, and any one campaign will likely take you several play sessions to complete.Cons: It can be a real grind to earn your in-game gold to purchase game table elements or the player character gear and upgrades. There is an option to buy the gold, but I don't recommend it when a few rounds in a dungeon with adequate healing potions will do the trick. The music can also get redundant very quickly unless you learn to tune it out.Replayable: Yes. Very yes. Simple enough to pick up on a whim, immersive enough to feel different every time you play without becoming boring.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												The fact that I've amassed 30 hours on this since its most recent sale a week ago should suggest just how much I'm enjoying this game. While at times it has seemed to drag on (particularly with some of the fetch quests, but what game with fetch quests DOESN'T drag at those points really), I have thoroughly enjoyed the experience of what is effectively D'n'D in video game form.I think the one thing I've enjoyed the most about this experience though is that you control exactly how easy/hard the game is for more or less the duration of the game. For about 90% of the battles, you decide just how many monsters you face, whether you make it easy on yourself and just take on one small bat for minimal but easy exp, or whether you take on a horde of Invaders for major risk/reward exp/gold - a concept which I thought is pretty damn neat. Along with being able to change your party at any point in the game (with more classes to unlock as you playthrough), you can really make the experience your own every time and try all sorts of weird and wonderful combinations.Fun addicting title with neat graphics and a good soundtrack that I'm sure I'll be playing for many many moons to come.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												The first thing that really impressed me about KoPaP+1, is that it recognised my eyefinity multi-monitor setup without skipping a beat and started in native resolution on my central (designated no. 1) monitor. The second is the pixel art, which is sumptious and extremely well done.This is a light and amusing game, paying homage to tabletop RPGs and early 90s cRPGs. If you have reservations in respect of the gold buying facility which is apparently a feature of the tablet versions, it is disabled in the PC version. At first I found the concept a little too meta and self-referential, but the humour grew on me to the point where I found myself laughing and recalling real pen and paper sessions where the GM and players said almost exactly the same things the characters in game were saying.If you are trying for full completion of achievements, keep in mind that your gold is common between all your saved games, so you can accumulate a good amount of reserves to equip the uber party you create for the 365/465 day completion achieve. This is probably the most elusive while the similarly rare 50 dungeon complete achieve requires no particular strategy except an appetite for doing the same thing over and over again. I've found resetting or upgrading a party which has completed the game and replaying the content at a higher level to be the best way of accumulating gold for such an attempt.Wait for a decent sale price and you will get at least 25hrs of entertainment for a reasonable sum.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												The main knock against this game is the grind that ruins the entire experience. The whole game seems like it's built to try to get you to buy gold for real money with micro-transactions. Everything from the meager drops from enemies to the fact that you have to pay gold to upgrade the blacksmith to the fact that upgrading weapons and armor always has a failure chance requiring you to spend even more gold. Even the in-game methods of boosting your gold gain almost always come at the expense of experience which in turn prevents you from mitigating the one thing that you're most likely trying to escape from: the grind. The whole time I was playing this I could feel it reaching for my wallet... in spite of the fact that this feature has apparently been removed from the game.And this is really a shame because it's not a bad game in any other aspect. The combat is the core of the game and, while basic, it's pretty solid. I never found myself feeling overpowered or like there was no aspect of challenge to it; nor did I ever feel like the game had pushed me into a corner where I was helpless. Even though you have very few abilities to choose from, there is depth and strategy in how they're use. The pixel-art backgrounds are good and contain a lot of cool references. It's kinda cool and chilling when you go to an area to level-grind and notice after an hour that slenderman has been standing there the whole time. I personally found the humor a bit flat and irreverent... though also occasionally spot-on speaking as someone who's played the tabletop RPGs this game is supposedly an homage to.Bottom line: If you like level grinding or have a high enough tolerance for it to see the rest of the experience though then this is the game for you. For me, I've found the game too tedious to play at length and it's not worth spending hours farming gold for the meager amounts of story and the occasional chuckle. Maybe it gets better later on, but it doesn't feel worth it to me to spend the time slogging through it.And for anyone who says "This is SOOOoo much like D&D"... no, it's not. At least, not if you have a good DM it isn't. ;)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												If you're looking for a quirky, fun RPG that simulates the basics of a game of Dungeons and Dragons, then this game is worth trying out. You are given a selection of players with different passive abilities, and are able to invite them to your game as the class of your choice. New players and classes can be rotated in, and you have control over everyone's skills, equipment upgrades and accessories, but not their base stats. You are able to switch Dungeon Masters, furniture, and table items that add bonuses to your game, as well as purchase perishable food items which give temporary bonuses to players.Fully upgrading your equipment and game room does require grinding for experience and gold, and the game is plagued by seemingly random difficulty jumps as the recommended levels for quests start to outpace your characters' growth even if you complete the optional quest lines. Despite this, the game is still quite enjoyable and charming, as long as you have a soft spot for old school RPGs. However those looking for a compelling narrative are going to be disappointed, as the game's dialogue is riddled with generic stereotypes and frequent grammar mistakes.So if you're looking for a traditional turn-based RPG with some D&D flair to spend hours slaughtering monsters and levelling up your characters, then this is your game. If that sounds boring and repetitive to you, or if you require an epic story and interesting characters, then you may want to pass on this one.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												On the whole this is a fun little RPG that hearkens back to tabletop DnD. But it's not without a few significant flaws in my opinion.Pros:1) Good concept and basic game design2) Combat involves some strategy - while combat has some RNG components, by and large strategy will win/lose most matches3) "Bonus" purchases are creative and allow for nice customizationCons:1) "Crafting" system is almost entirely RNG. A bad streak of rolls and you can come away with nothing.  Equipment upgrades are relatively expensive without significant off-quest grinding, and even levelling up the Blacksmith and maxing out luck bonuses, the chance of failure is still relatively high for items of that expense.  2) This problem is exacerbated by 'mining' being the primary means to upgrade said blacksmith. Relatively few nodes vs. a steep cost-scaling, and a needlessly long dialogue (which can't be interrupted best I can tell) each time you attempt to mine a node makes it like pulling teeth after level 3-4.  At BS level 7, even with bonuses my risk of failure is about 20-25%.  And perhaps due to bad luck, I think my actual failure rate is closer to 40%.  3) The design feature that has certain quest types trigger combat as you hit each zone is reasonable in the early game, and incredibly annoying in the late game. As a lvl 35 party, what's the point of slowing the game for me to have repeated battles against lvl 5 enemies?On the whole it's a good game, and it's probably going to take the average player 12-20 hours to play through the main campaign. While side quests are technically optional, end-game battles are much higher level than you'd likely manage if you just skipped through. Regular mobs can be cc'ed regardless of your level (so at worst you can slog through a long fight even if overmatched), but elites/bosses cannot.It will be interesting to see what improvements they make for the 2nd game due out this fall.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												You can probably tell at a glance whether you will like this game. If you are a fan of the Pixel Art style and enjoy RPGs, then you will love Knights of Pen and Paper. Otherwise, move along. This game is quirky, entertaining, and more robust than a lot of people give it credit for. The last game I bought on Steam before Knights of Pen and Paper was Final Fantasy III, and I have to say, I actually think KoPaP has a better class system than FFIII. I certainly enjoyed it a lot more. There are six classes available at first, with another six that you can unlock for future playthroughs by completing side quests throughout the game. Each class has four abilities which you can upgrade over time as the character levels up. These abilities can either be passive (increasing attack power, critical chance, physical resistance, etc.) or active (dealing extra damage, buffing friendly units, etc.), and the variety of different classes and different abilities means that you can come up with different strategies and play styles on each and every playthrough.This game has a ton of replay value. Setting up a unique and balanced party is half the fun--the other half is learning how to make the most out of the combinations you choose. And since each of the twelve (or seventeen) playable characters has unique traits as well (such as extra experience, extra luck, or skill bonuses), this game provides way more variety between one playthrough and the next than you might think from the "casual" label the game has earned from a lot of people. Furthermore, KoPaP's gameplay successfully solves some of the problems inherent in turn-based RPGs--including Final Fantasy III. Turn order is determined at random at the start of every battle (bases on each character and enemy's Initiative stat), but it stays the same throughout the entire battle. Thus, the game allows you to strategize, knowing exactly which characters get to move when, but still introduces an element of randomness that makes every battle feel unique. Consecutive fights against the exact same enemies will play out differently and require slightly different strategies.Visually, KoPaP makes clever and effective use of the faux-8-bit style that's currently so popular in indie games. When characters from other Behold Studios games appear as part of certain quests, the humorously obvious contrast between the blocky KoPaP characters and the much higher-resolution guest characters serves to remind you that this game looks the way it does as a matter of choice--not of hardware or software limitations. The backgrounds in nearly every area you visit are loaded with minimalistically rendered pop culture references, from Lord of the Rings to Captain America. But these references get annoying quickly once they start working their way into the game's main plotlines. What is amusing as a background easter egg comes across as cheesy, clunky, and unfitting as a major foreground element. The game tries to spin these pop culture interpositions as an inside joke about how real-world RPG dungeon masters come up with their material, but the joke, in my opinion, falls flat. Therein lies one potential pitfall of the game: KoPaP derives most of its humor from stereotypes and inside jokes about real-world RPG players. Sometimes, the game strikes on some genuinely amusing and accessible ideas. All of the original twelve playable characters are pretty funny--from Hynx (the hardcore guy who came up with his own lame fantasy name) to Mr. John (the totally normal business man who plays in his scanty spare time) to Grandma (who doesn't know what's going on and wants everyone else to speak up). But after a few hours, you'll probably be pretty bored with characters complaining about stupid quests. Or asking for the hundredth time whether someone can order a pizza. Or worse, laughing at the game's own jokes. Self-congratulation is never funny or desirable in a video game.The game has other flaws as well. KoPaP was made by a Brazilian company, which is really cool. But the localization is really spotty, and--especially as you get closer to the end of the game--a lot of the dialogue is totally garbled and difficult to make out. Given how much of the humor and plot of this game depends on dialogue for delivery, that's a pretty serious problem. Also, outside of a single box of flavor text when you first create a character, none of the playable characters has any unique dialogue. Each character simply gets assigned different lines of text that are the exact same on every playthrough. And while it can be amusing to hear Grandma complain about why there aren't more hot girls in the game's quests, the canned dialogue gets old once you've already seen it once or twice. For the most part, the game does a good job "scaling" enemies so that you are always at an appropriate level to tackle  the main storyline quests. But towards the end of the game, more enemies gain powerful abilities that can make them much harder than their level suggests. You will face some frustrations from enemies that are pushovers in one battle and obliterate you in the next. The game also helpfully tells you approximately what level of enemies you will face in any specific quest. But there are a lot of mistakes--particularly on quests that have you going to multiple locations or that show up as a set--which can lead to you stumbling into difficult areas before you're ready (or abandoning a quest halfway through). Really, I can only see two truly "casual" elements to this game. First, you can save and quit at any point when you aren't fighting enemies. It's a nice touch, since it means you can play this game for five minutes or two hours. But, second, this game shows its "casual" nature in that you will probably start to get bored if you play for much more than an hour or an hour-and-a-half at once. For one thing, the game's story is pretty goofy and trivial--more entertaining than engrossing. And there are only so many variations on the "go to X, battle Y" formula that the game can throw you before it gets a little tiresome. Seriously. The gameplay in this game consists entirely of traveling to different areas and fighting different enemies. Of course, combat is fun and engaging, but the game is still better in small doses.If all that sounds appealing to you, then buy this game. I bought it on sale, and I have really enjoyed it. It's just fun!

												It's worth playing, but worth a lot less than the asking price.  It's a cute game and it' s funny, but the gameplay really suffers.  The escort missions are really awful and greatly detract from the overall experience with forced encounters that pose no challenge or threat and simply waste your time.  Another bad mission is the "gather the 5 desert flowers... 8 furs... 5 glitches..." It's quite contrived, which doesn't help when the story is very minimalistic.  The overworld map is the absolute enemy to this game.  That map really ruins the pacing of the game, if moving from one location to another wasn't so boring and time-comsuming the game would feel a lot better.  The combat is good, but could be improved.  If the enemies could have more interesting abilities then the grindy nature of game could be helped a lot.  It would be great if there were more D&D-like mechanics included, because that would be appropriate with the theme and would be fun.  It's art and style were fun enough for me to recommend, but if you were looking for an good RPG then look elsewhere.

Posted: February 10, 2015
												Knights of Pen and Paper is an RPG within an RPG : as a dungeon master, you gather a team of friends to be "the characters you'll play with", and each of your characters play another character inside the grand adventure of roleplaying, Inception style. Cool, uh ?The "fictional adventure" is decent, but not very original or engaging unless you're a stat junkie or easily fall for nostalgia. The "game night advenure" is a complete static one and takes place around a table. From this point, your options to level things up are limited to your vicinity. And that's kinda boring even depressive the envision your progression as providing junk food or changing furniture. I thought the real joy of a gaming night was the emotions shared by the players.Maybe the game should have been more accurately named Gaming Buddies of Ikea and Superstores. Didn't worked for me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												The first thing that really impressed me about KoPaP+1, is that it recognised my eyefinity multi-monitor setup without skipping a beat and started in native resolution on my central (designated no. 1) monitor. The second is the pixel art, which is sumptious and extremely well done.This is a light and amusing game, paying homage to tabletop RPGs and early 90s cRPGs. If you have reservations in respect of the gold buying facility which is apparently a feature of the tablet versions, it is disabled in the PC version. At first I found the concept a little too meta and self-referential, but the humour grew on me to the point where I found myself laughing and recalling real pen and paper sessions where the GM and players said almost exactly the same things the characters in game were saying.If you are trying for full completion of achievements, keep in mind that your gold is common between all your saved games, so you can accumulate a good amount of reserves to equip the uber party you create for the 365/465 day completion achieve. This is probably the most elusive while the similarly rare 50 dungeon complete achieve requires no particular strategy except an appetite for doing the same thing over and over again. I've found resetting or upgrading a party which has completed the game and replaying the content at a higher level to be the best way of accumulating gold for such an attempt.Wait for a decent sale price and you will get at least 25hrs of entertainment for a reasonable sum.

Grade: 96/100Difficulty: Easy.Pros: If you've ever played a tabletop game, this is a walk in the park. The humor and references make it fun to play. The variety of options adds a lot of depth to the game, and any one campaign will likely take you several play sessions to complete.Cons: It can be a real grind to earn your in-game gold to purchase game table elements or the player character gear and upgrades. There is an option to buy the gold, but I don't recommend it when a few rounds in a dungeon with adequate healing potions will do the trick. The music can also get redundant very quickly unless you learn to tune it out.Replayable: Yes. Very yes. Simple enough to pick up on a whim, immersive enough to feel different every time you play without becoming boring.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												If you're an old school fan of Dungeons & Dragons and don't have the time to play an epic RPG, this game is for you. You do NOT need to buy any microtransactions in this game as long as you manage you money ok (read the guides and use +gold bonus modifiers). I like the fact that you have the option to play in different screen resolutions as well as in a windowed mode where you can multitask.This game takes turn-based RPG to its roots. Newer gamers may not appreciate it, but it is right for older gamers with busy lives. It is sprinkled with pop culture and various references throughout the game. It may get repetitive at times, but there are various classes to keep things fresh.The game doesn't do a very good job in explaining that you can mine rocks in caves for grindstone, and then take the stones to a town to raise the XP of the blacksmith. I would not suggest attempting to level up weapons and armors until later in the game since the success rate is so low. Reading the tips and guides will make your experience more enjoyable and you won't be wasting your hard-earned gold (since gold is used for everything, including travel).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Allow me to preface this review by saying that I do like it and that this is an increbily fun game. That being said, there are big flaws that are constantly nagging at me, slowly becoming worse as I continue to play. I DO recommend this game, and also kinda not. I'll try to explain below.Let's start with the positives:- Each job feels unique. The jobs are varied significantly, each having their own abilities and "hat" that goes onto the player's. The players themselves each have a skill that they bring to the table and it's fun to min/max or switch out players with different jobs to see what they would work best as.- The art direction is classic and very colourful. The art direction reminds me a lot of the older FF games, and a few other sprite-based games that were brought out in the 90s and early 2000s. It's simple, colourful, and nice to look at. Nothing is too washed out and the colour choice isn't offensive to the eye.- Cute references to Sci-Fi and Fantasy stories.There are TONS of references to various shows, books, movies, ect littered throughout the game world. It's cute seeing the Tardis in the desert or fighting a Ninja Turtle in the sewers. I won't spoil any more for anyone reading this review, but I will say that if you don't mind referential humour then you will certainly enjoy many bits of this game.- The music can be pretty enjoyable.The music is simple, but not in a bad way. It feels a bit like the old Mario games in places. I'm afraid I can't really elaborate on exactly what I mean, sufficed to say that the music fits the areas that it's in.So what about the negatives? Well, I'm afraid that this is where a majority of my review is going to be focused. There are quite a lot of issues littered throughout the game that bug me and I'll try to elaborate on why that is.- The referential humor.Okay, I know what you're all thinking, "Hey, didn't you just list that as a positive?" Well, yes, and it is... However, I also feel it's a bit of a negative. This game is a little too busy referencing so many things that it's a bit hard to tell where the references end and the original content begins. For instance, most of the player characters are references to either real life people or fictional people. Which this doesn't bother me too much, I do feel like it wasn't really needed. Is it really so hard to come up with original player characters? Well, apparently not, I mean, there are some. So why did we need a Paris Hilton or Ramona Flowers allusion? Also, the "Game Dev Gang" joke was cute at first but it got old way too fast. I may be the only one that's really bothered by this but this is a bias review so... Yeah.- Job abilities.Simply put? There aren't enough/ They're too easily unlocked. The jobs -are- still distinct from one another, I can't take that away. However, there's something to be said about being limited to four abilities. That, of course, being "why?" I'm not ignorant, I know you can only realistically fit in so many on a game that was originally a mobile game- but, this isn't a mobile platform I'm playing it on, this is the PC edition. Why are jobs so limited? Some jobs have 2 passive abilities and 2 abilities you need to activate. That doesn't seem right to me. For example: The Cleric job has a focus heal, a group heal, a divine attack that restores HP, and a Attack down debuff that spreads to 3 enemies. Those are all fine and dandy, but why doesn't it have a manner of Dispel? How about a passive ability to not be harmed by Divine attacks or something along those lines? This may be a nit-pick, but this is what was nagging me as I use certain characters. Now, that being said, I also feel that being able to unlock any of a job's abilities at any level is... Questionable. Again, might just be a nit-pick, maybe it only bothers me.- Enemy Encounters.I'll keep this one short: Add a 'random' option to the 'enemy choice' screen. I get what they're going for, allowing the player to pick the enemies your group encounters so as to best simulate both the DM and Player experience, but I don't feel like you should -always- have your cake and eat it like that. Dungeons are good for random encounters.- Missing Dialogue/ Lack of Personality for the PlayersThere are moments in the various quests or on the world map when your players are either talking to an NPC or casually interacting with the "DM" of the group that, honestly, feel like they have dialogue missing from them. For instance, sometimes I'll have completed a quest and the NPC will say something along the lines of, "Oh, thank you! You're so helpful." I'll click to go to the next bit of dialogue, presumebly what the player would say to the NPC, but there's... Nothing. A blank screen that I click through to go to my quest rewards. What? It's even worse when there are times where an entire half of a conversation is missing- or the players don't react to what was said in any realistic manner. The grammar has mistakes on occasion, as well. So, the dialogue seems missing. That's a pretty big problem in-and-of itself, but then you couple that with none of the players, DMs, NPCs, even the enemies, having -any- kind of distinct personality? Well, that just rubs me the wrong way. In this age of having defined characters, enemies, and even monsters in our stories, this feels lazy. Hopelessly lazy.- A lack of any kind of multiplayer support.This game would be a MUCH better experience if I could get a group of five other friends to play with me, with someone to DM and actually create custom quests or something. Alas, that is not available here.So, before I continue on for a few hours, what am I saying with all of this? This game, in all honesty, is just decent. It's a decent game and I enjoy it, but it is weighed down by some pretty substantial flaws. I enjoy it for what it is and would play it again, even if a grain of salt has to be taken with it. If they fix these problems, then fantastic. This would be an excellent game. As it stands right now, I recommend it- but only if you think you can handle the flaws.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												Let me start off by saying that I actually liked this game. However, there's A LOT of small problems with the game that make it not very fun or enjoyable. I was really excited to play this and was pretty disappointed halfway through and was completely over it by the end.- The class and character systemThis had the potential to be really cool and in-depth but classes are limited to 4 abilities and never change. There aren't any skill trees or advancing skills, you get the same 4 skills from the beginning to the end, the only thing changing are the numbers tied to each skill. This got boring really fast. The unique character system is kind of pointless, characters range from useful, to slightly useful, to pointless. Who would you rather have, the guy with +3 attack or the guy who only has +1 attack? The guy with +5 health who's more likely to live or the guy who costs -50% gold to revive after he dies because he sucks? Most of them are just pointless, especially after you unlock the game devs and restart your game.-Lack of plotI know that this is supposed to be more of a comedy/parody type thing, and I appreciated the humor, but the whole lack of an actual plot just made the game feel even more boring when you tie in the tedious and boring gameplay.-Boring gameplayJust keep clicking on the same skills over and over. Fight mobs without any sort of auto-battle or anything to streamline grinding (and trust me, there's a lot of grinding). On a PC this is the worst thing. Obviously if you have a touch screen computer (like I do) or play this game on a mobile platform (which obviously isn't the Steam version) then it's not so bad but still. Sitting there and clicking the same♥♥♥♥♥♥over and over gets boring really fast. The beginning of the game is fun because you're still new to everything and your skills and levels are rising fast, but everything plateaus equally as fast, especially the fun.-Gold systemEverything in this game costs gold except for leveling up. Consumables cost gold, accessories cost an obscene amount of gold, TRAVELING costs gold (this is one of the stupidest things ever), reviving your dead characters cost gold and most quests cost gold as a result of traveling (despite them usually refunding the gold, if you don't have the initial gold you will have to grind). Now, this doesn't SOUND like that big a deal, but grinding gold is unbelievably slow. You can spend about half an hour to grind about 1000 or so gold through the early to mid game. To upgrade all of your characters' armor from lvl1 to lvl2 would cost roughly 1000+ and that's assuming you succeed because upgrading equips usually has a 50% and below chance to upgrade unless you invest either MORE GOLD or grind mines to upgrade your blacksmith. There's upgrades that increase your gold income rate but they don't do very much. The whole thing is just terrible.There's not much the game does right, but what they actually DO right is pretty good.+BalanceThis is one of the few indie/joke/whatever RPGs that has actual balance. Most of them either don't try to have any semblance of balance and are too easy just so they can spout more ♥♥♥♥♥♥ memes. This actually feels like a really well done game and the battle mechanics were well thought out. It doesn't feel like there are any OP classes. Yeah, the rogue and hunter are really strong, but they're not overpowered. The game is decently challenging from beginning to end and never feels too easy or ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t hard. This is pretty hard to do so I have to commend the creators.+HumorThis is a pretty funny game, lots of humor and lightheartedness, but it's an actual game. There are way too many ♥♥♥♥♥♥ indie games that just try to shove unfunny jokes everywhere and lack actual content. This game has both and once again, the creators did a good job.Overall thoughts: I actually liked this game and had a good time playing it, it just has a lot of flaws. However, I also only paid about $4 for this and the DLC. If I had paid the full $15 for both I would have been extremely upset as this game does not provide for more than a couple of dollars worth of entertainment. As far as replay value goes, I don't want to ever play this again. It'll just remind me of how disappointed I was the first time playing it. If you can grab it for a couple of dollars (preferably the mobile version, avoid the steam version) go for it, but don't bother paying full price for this.

Posted: June 7, 2015
												Nice game with lots of in-jokes for whoever has ever played D&D in their life (plus a good amount of geeky references in general). The game is mostly combat though, and the combat is as classic a turn based RPG combat as it can get - any SNES Final Fantasy had a similar system with more depth. This, combined with the fact that the game is pretty grind-y, makes the gameplay rather repetitive. Buy it only in offer and only if you like the idea of the "meta" RPG jokes.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Allow me to preface this review by saying that I do like it and that this is an increbily fun game. That being said, there are big flaws that are constantly nagging at me, slowly becoming worse as I continue to play. I DO recommend this game, and also kinda not. I'll try to explain below.Let's start with the positives:- Each job feels unique. The jobs are varied significantly, each having their own abilities and "hat" that goes onto the player's. The players themselves each have a skill that they bring to the table and it's fun to min/max or switch out players with different jobs to see what they would work best as.- The art direction is classic and very colourful. The art direction reminds me a lot of the older FF games, and a few other sprite-based games that were brought out in the 90s and early 2000s. It's simple, colourful, and nice to look at. Nothing is too washed out and the colour choice isn't offensive to the eye.- Cute references to Sci-Fi and Fantasy stories.There are TONS of references to various shows, books, movies, ect littered throughout the game world. It's cute seeing the Tardis in the desert or fighting a Ninja Turtle in the sewers. I won't spoil any more for anyone reading this review, but I will say that if you don't mind referential humour then you will certainly enjoy many bits of this game.- The music can be pretty enjoyable.The music is simple, but not in a bad way. It feels a bit like the old Mario games in places. I'm afraid I can't really elaborate on exactly what I mean, sufficed to say that the music fits the areas that it's in.So what about the negatives? Well, I'm afraid that this is where a majority of my review is going to be focused. There are quite a lot of issues littered throughout the game that bug me and I'll try to elaborate on why that is.- The referential humor.Okay, I know what you're all thinking, "Hey, didn't you just list that as a positive?" Well, yes, and it is... However, I also feel it's a bit of a negative. This game is a little too busy referencing so many things that it's a bit hard to tell where the references end and the original content begins. For instance, most of the player characters are references to either real life people or fictional people. Which this doesn't bother me too much, I do feel like it wasn't really needed. Is it really so hard to come up with original player characters? Well, apparently not, I mean, there are some. So why did we need a Paris Hilton or Ramona Flowers allusion? Also, the "Game Dev Gang" joke was cute at first but it got old way too fast. I may be the only one that's really bothered by this but this is a bias review so... Yeah.- Job abilities.Simply put? There aren't enough/ They're too easily unlocked. The jobs -are- still distinct from one another, I can't take that away. However, there's something to be said about being limited to four abilities. That, of course, being "why?" I'm not ignorant, I know you can only realistically fit in so many on a game that was originally a mobile game- but, this isn't a mobile platform I'm playing it on, this is the PC edition. Why are jobs so limited? Some jobs have 2 passive abilities and 2 abilities you need to activate. That doesn't seem right to me. For example: The Cleric job has a focus heal, a group heal, a divine attack that restores HP, and a Attack down debuff that spreads to 3 enemies. Those are all fine and dandy, but why doesn't it have a manner of Dispel? How about a passive ability to not be harmed by Divine attacks or something along those lines? This may be a nit-pick, but this is what was nagging me as I use certain characters. Now, that being said, I also feel that being able to unlock any of a job's abilities at any level is... Questionable. Again, might just be a nit-pick, maybe it only bothers me.- Enemy Encounters.I'll keep this one short: Add a 'random' option to the 'enemy choice' screen. I get what they're going for, allowing the player to pick the enemies your group encounters so as to best simulate both the DM and Player experience, but I don't feel like you should -always- have your cake and eat it like that. Dungeons are good for random encounters.- Missing Dialogue/ Lack of Personality for the PlayersThere are moments in the various quests or on the world map when your players are either talking to an NPC or casually interacting with the "DM" of the group that, honestly, feel like they have dialogue missing from them. For instance, sometimes I'll have completed a quest and the NPC will say something along the lines of, "Oh, thank you! You're so helpful." I'll click to go to the next bit of dialogue, presumebly what the player would say to the NPC, but there's... Nothing. A blank screen that I click through to go to my quest rewards. What? It's even worse when there are times where an entire half of a conversation is missing- or the players don't react to what was said in any realistic manner. The grammar has mistakes on occasion, as well. So, the dialogue seems missing. That's a pretty big problem in-and-of itself, but then you couple that with none of the players, DMs, NPCs, even the enemies, having -any- kind of distinct personality? Well, that just rubs me the wrong way. In this age of having defined characters, enemies, and even monsters in our stories, this feels lazy. Hopelessly lazy.- A lack of any kind of multiplayer support.This game would be a MUCH better experience if I could get a group of five other friends to play with me, with someone to DM and actually create custom quests or something. Alas, that is not available here.So, before I continue on for a few hours, what am I saying with all of this? This game, in all honesty, is just decent. It's a decent game and I enjoy it, but it is weighed down by some pretty substantial flaws. I enjoy it for what it is and would play it again, even if a grain of salt has to be taken with it. If they fix these problems, then fantastic. This would be an excellent game. As it stands right now, I recommend it- but only if you think you can handle the flaws.

Posted: December 17, 2013
												I grew up on the NES and DOS-era RPGs, but I have not played any edition of Dungeons and Dragons earlier than third.  That said, I am quite familiar with the mechanics and culture that this game is paying homage to.  It fits the feel of an 8-bit RPG and a 1980s homebrew campaign world quite well, with its crunchy (mechanics-focused) gameplay and cobbled-together story.I love this game so far, despite the grind, but it is most certainly not for everyone. I got it for Christmas, and if one can find it for $5 or less, it is worth buying if you like that sort of thing. I do, and they fixed their issues with microtaransaction elements, so I'm editing my review to reflect that.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												I can't remember why exactly i bought this, nor do i care. This is a great game. I bought the five dollar expansion almost immediatly after playing a few missions because i didn't want to miss a thing. The game takes after DnD in that your players are a group of nerds at a table, being guided through an adventure by a GM. This opens up possibilities for excellent 4th wall breaks and humorous diolalogue, something the devs took full adventege of. The retro styles is pleasing to the eye and, just when i though i had beaten the game, a ton more suddenly opened up. The open endedness of the game was a huge selling point for me. There are clear idicators letting you know which way the plot lies, but you are free to explore wherever the heck you please. Suggestions are given for how strong you ought ot be before you go to different locations so you aren't unduely surprised when your two level ten boys are jumped by a level 25 wraith. There are cons of course. Items and items drops in general are poor, but gold is very easy to get ahold of while still making you work for it, so you can purchase the good items with moderate hassle. There is a fair amount of grinding, but it doesn't have to be samey if you don't let it. Honestly, this is a very good game and extremely well worth the price. 9.5/10.

												This is a very nice casual game, as it manages to keep you entertained for quite a decent amount of time. You start with a certain party and then while you're advancing in the campaign, you get to unlock other classes or upgrades that improve the gameplay experience. It's worth to mention that the graphics are simple and the soundtrack is also very limited, but you might as well just turn off the music and listen to a radio station (something that I usually do). There're also the trading cards and achievements available, which is something that might add for the replay value factor. Overall, this is the kind of game to play bit by bit, I really don't recommend to experience for straight hours because it might start to wear down on you quite easily.

Posted: April 28, 2015
												Knights of Pen and Paper is not a standard RPG.  But it is.If you ever spent time at a kitchen table hashing out battles between your elf ranger and heaps of orcs, you'll recognize 99% of what's going on in this game.  If not, the jokes may wear faster than Holy Grail references at your girlfriend's house.Fun, interesting mechanics keep the battles at varying levels of difficulty, and the party dynamics are interesting as well.  A great, fun rimp for RPG fans, and a special treat for tabletop role-players.  TL;DR: 10/10, would die during character creation again.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												Let me start off by saying that I actually liked this game. However, there's A LOT of small problems with the game that make it not very fun or enjoyable. I was really excited to play this and was pretty disappointed halfway through and was completely over it by the end.- The class and character systemThis had the potential to be really cool and in-depth but classes are limited to 4 abilities and never change. There aren't any skill trees or advancing skills, you get the same 4 skills from the beginning to the end, the only thing changing are the numbers tied to each skill. This got boring really fast. The unique character system is kind of pointless, characters range from useful, to slightly useful, to pointless. Who would you rather have, the guy with +3 attack or the guy who only has +1 attack? The guy with +5 health who's more likely to live or the guy who costs -50% gold to revive after he dies because he sucks? Most of them are just pointless, especially after you unlock the game devs and restart your game.-Lack of plotI know that this is supposed to be more of a comedy/parody type thing, and I appreciated the humor, but the whole lack of an actual plot just made the game feel even more boring when you tie in the tedious and boring gameplay.-Boring gameplayJust keep clicking on the same skills over and over. Fight mobs without any sort of auto-battle or anything to streamline grinding (and trust me, there's a lot of grinding). On a PC this is the worst thing. Obviously if you have a touch screen computer (like I do) or play this game on a mobile platform (which obviously isn't the Steam version) then it's not so bad but still. Sitting there and clicking the same♥♥♥♥♥♥over and over gets boring really fast. The beginning of the game is fun because you're still new to everything and your skills and levels are rising fast, but everything plateaus equally as fast, especially the fun.-Gold systemEverything in this game costs gold except for leveling up. Consumables cost gold, accessories cost an obscene amount of gold, TRAVELING costs gold (this is one of the stupidest things ever), reviving your dead characters cost gold and most quests cost gold as a result of traveling (despite them usually refunding the gold, if you don't have the initial gold you will have to grind). Now, this doesn't SOUND like that big a deal, but grinding gold is unbelievably slow. You can spend about half an hour to grind about 1000 or so gold through the early to mid game. To upgrade all of your characters' armor from lvl1 to lvl2 would cost roughly 1000+ and that's assuming you succeed because upgrading equips usually has a 50% and below chance to upgrade unless you invest either MORE GOLD or grind mines to upgrade your blacksmith. There's upgrades that increase your gold income rate but they don't do very much. The whole thing is just terrible.There's not much the game does right, but what they actually DO right is pretty good.+BalanceThis is one of the few indie/joke/whatever RPGs that has actual balance. Most of them either don't try to have any semblance of balance and are too easy just so they can spout more ♥♥♥♥♥♥ memes. This actually feels like a really well done game and the battle mechanics were well thought out. It doesn't feel like there are any OP classes. Yeah, the rogue and hunter are really strong, but they're not overpowered. The game is decently challenging from beginning to end and never feels too easy or ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t hard. This is pretty hard to do so I have to commend the creators.+HumorThis is a pretty funny game, lots of humor and lightheartedness, but it's an actual game. There are way too many ♥♥♥♥♥♥ indie games that just try to shove unfunny jokes everywhere and lack actual content. This game has both and once again, the creators did a good job.Overall thoughts: I actually liked this game and had a good time playing it, it just has a lot of flaws. However, I also only paid about $4 for this and the DLC. If I had paid the full $15 for both I would have been extremely upset as this game does not provide for more than a couple of dollars worth of entertainment. As far as replay value goes, I don't want to ever play this again. It'll just remind me of how disappointed I was the first time playing it. If you can grab it for a couple of dollars (preferably the mobile version, avoid the steam version) go for it, but don't bother paying full price for this.

												KPP is a small, yet clever and fun game. You build your party of players, and let the DM take you through the magical, tedious universe of a classic D20 tabletop game.Travel to different areas on the map to battle monsters and complete quests. Collect gold and use it to buy items, equipment, even go meta and spend your gold on a pizza for the table. It's everything you might expect from the title.Overall, it's pretty straight-forward, simple, classicly repititve, and surprisingly charming. $10-15 is a little much, but definitely grab it when it goes on sale.Sidenote: Plays well on an x86 tablet, using only touch gestures.

Posted: February 16, 2015
												30% of this game is doing quests. You go to one place, learn what the quest is about, go to another place, kill a bunch of monsters on your way, go back, collect reward.70% is grinding. The main difference is that now you can choose by yourself what monsters you want to fight.The fights, which are the core element of the game, use simple old-school JRPG mechanics. It gets tedious and repetitive.Item management and skill upgrades are simple. There isn't much room for creativity.The main gimmick (the player controlling not an adventurer, but a DM with his players who in turn control their adventurers) is OK, but it's not utilised to its fullest. In-game 4th wall breaking is a storytelling device and not a game mechanic.

Posted: February 24, 2014
												This game is awful. I got it in a bundle. It plays like Dragon Warrior (the ultimate example of why JRPGs are bad) but with microtransactions. The whole "real people playing a pnp RPG" concept is paper thin. It just gives you additional stats that directly update your combat abilities (e.g. buy a new gaming table and get +1 to attack) and stuff like that. The microtransaction angle is really heavily pushed on the player.It's a pure progress quest. Choose to churn through monster type "A" until they drop enough coins to afford the sword that can kill monster type "B." These developers should be boycotted for all of eternity. I'm really disappointed in Paradox for publishing it too. This has to be the most shallow, unethically money grubbing game they've ever put their name on. I can't imagine their cut of the sales would compensate them for being associated with this trash.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												I picked this game for the concept alone.  A game about characters playing a tabletop RPG.  While the premise sounds promising, it doesn't exactly follow that format which would have turned this game into a sim of sorts.  What it does present is an amusing Turn Based RPG game of the old days, from classics like Dragon Warrior to D&D.As someone who actually played D&D for a few years, this game was rather appealing.  Select your team of generic players and their class (and will wear a matching hat for said class) and start an adventure.  The game provides you what most RPG games tend to have: a sense of direction.  You're provided with the main storyline and a few side-quests to pick up some extra gold and exp.Be warned, this game has micro-transactions.  It is not a vital aspect of the game as you can earn gold by farming but it's only optional.  I personally do not approve of it but that should not stop other people from doing so.  Your money.If you are looking for a charming, turn-based RPG that is a bit out of the ordinary, check this title out.  I'm enjoying it so far.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												You can probably tell at a glance whether you will like this game. If you are a fan of the Pixel Art style and enjoy RPGs, then you will love Knights of Pen and Paper. Otherwise, move along. This game is quirky, entertaining, and more robust than a lot of people give it credit for. The last game I bought on Steam before Knights of Pen and Paper was Final Fantasy III, and I have to say, I actually think KoPaP has a better class system than FFIII. I certainly enjoyed it a lot more. There are six classes available at first, with another six that you can unlock for future playthroughs by completing side quests throughout the game. Each class has four abilities which you can upgrade over time as the character levels up. These abilities can either be passive (increasing attack power, critical chance, physical resistance, etc.) or active (dealing extra damage, buffing friendly units, etc.), and the variety of different classes and different abilities means that you can come up with different strategies and play styles on each and every playthrough.This game has a ton of replay value. Setting up a unique and balanced party is half the fun--the other half is learning how to make the most out of the combinations you choose. And since each of the twelve (or seventeen) playable characters has unique traits as well (such as extra experience, extra luck, or skill bonuses), this game provides way more variety between one playthrough and the next than you might think from the "casual" label the game has earned from a lot of people. Furthermore, KoPaP's gameplay successfully solves some of the problems inherent in turn-based RPGs--including Final Fantasy III. Turn order is determined at random at the start of every battle (bases on each character and enemy's Initiative stat), but it stays the same throughout the entire battle. Thus, the game allows you to strategize, knowing exactly which characters get to move when, but still introduces an element of randomness that makes every battle feel unique. Consecutive fights against the exact same enemies will play out differently and require slightly different strategies.Visually, KoPaP makes clever and effective use of the faux-8-bit style that's currently so popular in indie games. When characters from other Behold Studios games appear as part of certain quests, the humorously obvious contrast between the blocky KoPaP characters and the much higher-resolution guest characters serves to remind you that this game looks the way it does as a matter of choice--not of hardware or software limitations. The backgrounds in nearly every area you visit are loaded with minimalistically rendered pop culture references, from Lord of the Rings to Captain America. But these references get annoying quickly once they start working their way into the game's main plotlines. What is amusing as a background easter egg comes across as cheesy, clunky, and unfitting as a major foreground element. The game tries to spin these pop culture interpositions as an inside joke about how real-world RPG dungeon masters come up with their material, but the joke, in my opinion, falls flat. Therein lies one potential pitfall of the game: KoPaP derives most of its humor from stereotypes and inside jokes about real-world RPG players. Sometimes, the game strikes on some genuinely amusing and accessible ideas. All of the original twelve playable characters are pretty funny--from Hynx (the hardcore guy who came up with his own lame fantasy name) to Mr. John (the totally normal business man who plays in his scanty spare time) to Grandma (who doesn't know what's going on and wants everyone else to speak up). But after a few hours, you'll probably be pretty bored with characters complaining about stupid quests. Or asking for the hundredth time whether someone can order a pizza. Or worse, laughing at the game's own jokes. Self-congratulation is never funny or desirable in a video game.The game has other flaws as well. KoPaP was made by a Brazilian company, which is really cool. But the localization is really spotty, and--especially as you get closer to the end of the game--a lot of the dialogue is totally garbled and difficult to make out. Given how much of the humor and plot of this game depends on dialogue for delivery, that's a pretty serious problem. Also, outside of a single box of flavor text when you first create a character, none of the playable characters has any unique dialogue. Each character simply gets assigned different lines of text that are the exact same on every playthrough. And while it can be amusing to hear Grandma complain about why there aren't more hot girls in the game's quests, the canned dialogue gets old once you've already seen it once or twice. For the most part, the game does a good job "scaling" enemies so that you are always at an appropriate level to tackle  the main storyline quests. But towards the end of the game, more enemies gain powerful abilities that can make them much harder than their level suggests. You will face some frustrations from enemies that are pushovers in one battle and obliterate you in the next. The game also helpfully tells you approximately what level of enemies you will face in any specific quest. But there are a lot of mistakes--particularly on quests that have you going to multiple locations or that show up as a set--which can lead to you stumbling into difficult areas before you're ready (or abandoning a quest halfway through). Really, I can only see two truly "casual" elements to this game. First, you can save and quit at any point when you aren't fighting enemies. It's a nice touch, since it means you can play this game for five minutes or two hours. But, second, this game shows its "casual" nature in that you will probably start to get bored if you play for much more than an hour or an hour-and-a-half at once. For one thing, the game's story is pretty goofy and trivial--more entertaining than engrossing. And there are only so many variations on the "go to X, battle Y" formula that the game can throw you before it gets a little tiresome. Seriously. The gameplay in this game consists entirely of traveling to different areas and fighting different enemies. Of course, combat is fun and engaging, but the game is still better in small doses.If all that sounds appealing to you, then buy this game. I bought it on sale, and I have really enjoyed it. It's just fun!
