number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												With a name light "Knights of Pen and Paper" and with a UI designed around the table top, I expected to have fun with this game. That was not the case.One of the big problems with this game right off the bat is that each character has only 5 things they can do. Each of them can attack and then each class has 4 upgradable abilities, but some of them are passive. The problem here is that with a small margin of exception, there's no strategy to the fights. You either hit attack or you use abilities until you run out of mana.The problem with the skills themselves is that the level scaling is frankly horrendous, so if you don't focus on one of the 4 skills, you'll quickly reach a point where you can't play the game anymore because you'll just get trounced during every encounter. This means that you really need 4 characters for each class by the end of the game because if you have a level 20 fire mage and you're up against fire resistant creatures, then you're probably going to get your party killed. Another problem I have is the grinding. For a game that's supposed to be just a short cute DnD knockoff, there is an obscene amount of grinding. Example: "Collect 20 green apples". Well, green apples only drop from venus fly traps that take off half your health per attack and killing one isn't a guarantee that they will drop. So to get 20 green apples, you'll probably end up playing 12 encoutners against 3 venus fly traps. And that's just the beggining. The upgrade system is also based on grinding. You need to visit special areas where upgrades can be found (usually caves) then you need to roll a 20 sided dice and hope you get lucky just for the chance of getting an upgrade item. Once you have about 5-10 upgrade items (for your first upgrade) you then take it to a blacksmith who gives you a %chance that your item will be upgraded or he'll just waste your upgrade items. You can upgrade the blacksmith himself so that you're more likely to succeed, but that requires double or even triple the number of upgrade items you already needed, so now you need go to back to grinding in the caves. Plus, each character has 2 items (clothes and weapon) and when you remember that you need multiples of each class, you understand that you'll need hundreds and hundreds of grindstones just for a chance of upgrading your party. You'd think you could just ignore the upgrading, but because the level scaling is so unbalanced, you have to upgrade to proceed. Its just an awful time waster with no sense of progression and I'm glad I bought it on sale because this is literally a ported mobile game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												If you're looking for a quirky, fun RPG that simulates the basics of a game of Dungeons and Dragons, then this game is worth trying out. You are given a selection of players with different passive abilities, and are able to invite them to your game as the class of your choice. New players and classes can be rotated in, and you have control over everyone's skills, equipment upgrades and accessories, but not their base stats. You are able to switch Dungeon Masters, furniture, and table items that add bonuses to your game, as well as purchase perishable food items which give temporary bonuses to players.Fully upgrading your equipment and game room does require grinding for experience and gold, and the game is plagued by seemingly random difficulty jumps as the recommended levels for quests start to outpace your characters' growth even if you complete the optional quest lines. Despite this, the game is still quite enjoyable and charming, as long as you have a soft spot for old school RPGs. However those looking for a compelling narrative are going to be disappointed, as the game's dialogue is riddled with generic stereotypes and frequent grammar mistakes.So if you're looking for a traditional turn-based RPG with some D&D flair to spend hours slaughtering monsters and levelling up your characters, then this is your game. If that sounds boring and repetitive to you, or if you require an epic story and interesting characters, then you may want to pass on this one.

Posted: January 19, 2015
												Knights of Pen and Paper +1 Edition is a turn based RPG game set in a scenario that is a, well, table top pen and paper game, the game starts out with you choosing two starting party members from a specific selection of characters and classes, for example, a jock and a warrior, each character having their own little passive buffs, such as the Jock having a +1 to attack.Whilst the concept is nice, the gameplay tried and true, and characters, classes, and enemies all nicely diverse, and the quests a bit repetetive, you might begin to become a bit tired of doing the typical selection of escort, kill set number of enemies, or rescue quests, that is, only if you're not a fan of games such as this.Overall, the game is a fun one, with a humorous setting and story, I highly reccomend it if you're a fan of turn based RPGs, or RPGs in general, and even more so if you enjoy humorous games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												The first thing that really impressed me about KoPaP+1, is that it recognised my eyefinity multi-monitor setup without skipping a beat and started in native resolution on my central (designated no. 1) monitor. The second is the pixel art, which is sumptious and extremely well done.This is a light and amusing game, paying homage to tabletop RPGs and early 90s cRPGs. If you have reservations in respect of the gold buying facility which is apparently a feature of the tablet versions, it is disabled in the PC version. At first I found the concept a little too meta and self-referential, but the humour grew on me to the point where I found myself laughing and recalling real pen and paper sessions where the GM and players said almost exactly the same things the characters in game were saying.If you are trying for full completion of achievements, keep in mind that your gold is common between all your saved games, so you can accumulate a good amount of reserves to equip the uber party you create for the 365/465 day completion achieve. This is probably the most elusive while the similarly rare 50 dungeon complete achieve requires no particular strategy except an appetite for doing the same thing over and over again. I've found resetting or upgrading a party which has completed the game and replaying the content at a higher level to be the best way of accumulating gold for such an attempt.Wait for a decent sale price and you will get at least 25hrs of entertainment for a reasonable sum.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Knights of Pen and Paper has its charm, albeit it is not well-maintained throughout the game. The dialogues are funny, the characters and classes available for selection are varied, and its simple UI design makes it easy to get into. There are many features you can play around with, like the ability to decorate your room with items that grant bonuses to stats, and trying out different party setups after you've unlocked new classes and players. You also get to pick and choose which quests to do. The experience you receive from completing quests is also scaled according to your levels, so doing the lower level ones that you missed won't be a complete waste of your time when you're level grinding.On the minus side, the quests are fairly uninspired and they get repetitive. The battles eventually suffer from the same flaw as well. I only did the storyline quests and the ones that unlocked new classes. The story itself is also quite weak. There's nothing compelling or awe-inspiring to it. Having a great story is certainly not one of this game's selling points. Despite all the shortfalls, Knights of Pen and Paper can still keep you entertained for hours until the repetitiveness catches up and playing the game becomes more like a chore, where you're still playing because you haven't unlocked the other achievements yet.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												I have played and finished this game and it's lovely. If you have played some dungeon&dragons-like games in the past, it will bring fond memories. Some of the phrases and quips of the characters are spot on, and it all brings you back to that D&D atmosphere very well.The game principles are quite simple, there is a number of characters, each character has 4 skills, you can loot or buy wearable items and consumables, you can upgrade your weapons. Battles are turn-based, one action per turn. Simple, but also enjoyable and sufficient to help you enjoy yet another D&D adventure.The questing is well done, there is a main story line, but in any place you have a set of pre-created generic side quests that you can activate at any moment in order to gain more experience or items. You can also set up a custom fight any time. When setting up a fight, you choose how many and which creatures you're going to fight with, and the reward reflects that. I very much like this approach.There are a few dungeons in the game, which force you to stock up some healing items in the inventory if you want to explore it all, survive, and kill the boss. Again, similar to the D&D theme.There is good humor in the game, I liked it. After some hours it gets a bit repetitive, but it doesn't hold you up. The music is a bit more of a problem, there are just a few songs in the game, so it gets old quickly. A few more songs would be nice.Please note I've played this game on an Android tablet, not a PC, so I'm seeing this in a bit different perspective. The greatest benefit of this game for me was that it is an enjoyable game that can easily be played in a public transport during commuting, therefore offline and turn-based. This is an ideal game for your phone or tablet. If you intend to play this on PC, you might expect a bit more complex game mechanics, because you're fully concentrated on the game and you have a big screen. In that case, my opinion might not apply that well.Highly recommended, especially if you plan to play this on a mobile device (not the Steam version, though, of course).

												Knights of Pen and Paper +1 Edition is a turn based RPG game set in a scenario that is a, well, table top pen and paper game, the game starts out with you choosing two starting party members from a specific selection of characters and classes, for example, a jock and a warrior, each character having their own little passive buffs, such as the Jock having a +1 to attack.Whilst the concept is nice, the gameplay tried and true, and characters, classes, and enemies all nicely diverse, and the quests a bit repetetive, you might begin to become a bit tired of doing the typical selection of escort, kill set number of enemies, or rescue quests, that is, only if you're not a fan of games such as this.Overall, the game is a fun one, with a humorous setting and story, I highly reccomend it if you're a fan of turn based RPGs, or RPGs in general, and even more so if you enjoy humorous games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Knights of Pen and Paper has its charm, albeit it is not well-maintained throughout the game. The dialogues are funny, the characters and classes available for selection are varied, and its simple UI design makes it easy to get into. There are many features you can play around with, like the ability to decorate your room with items that grant bonuses to stats, and trying out different party setups after you've unlocked new classes and players. You also get to pick and choose which quests to do. The experience you receive from completing quests is also scaled according to your levels, so doing the lower level ones that you missed won't be a complete waste of your time when you're level grinding.On the minus side, the quests are fairly uninspired and they get repetitive. The battles eventually suffer from the same flaw as well. I only did the storyline quests and the ones that unlocked new classes. The story itself is also quite weak. There's nothing compelling or awe-inspiring to it. Having a great story is certainly not one of this game's selling points. Despite all the shortfalls, Knights of Pen and Paper can still keep you entertained for hours until the repetitiveness catches up and playing the game becomes more like a chore, where you're still playing because you haven't unlocked the other achievements yet.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Paradox Interactive and Behold Studios have created a labor of love with this little game.  This retro style RPG does an amazing job at bringing both the experience of a DnD session and a 90's style JRPG to you with plenty of toungue-in-cheek, modern humor to liven things up.  The classes are all very interesting and provide you with many unique ways to play their skills off of each other.  Battles are quickly paced and fairly designed; if you lose it's your fault.  If I had any critisism at it would be that the game is easier than it should be.  Granted, I grew up in the 90's so I'm a grizzled, RPG veteren at this point but I would still say a small difficulty spike would have raised this game to even greater heights.  If you have even a smidge of love for Pen and Paper style role play this game is a must purchase.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												I think I've played this game enough to give a basic review on the aspects of the game. Now, I'm going to go ahead and say that I like the style of this game, so I may be a bit biased. However, that does not matter as I will still be honest with this game.My reviews are typically divided into parts. Story, Gameplay, Music/Sounds, and Graphics. So let's get started!Graphics:I decided to start with graphics as they are the LEAST important when it comes to this review. This game is featured in 16 bit (I think) and looks quite good. In fact, you basically don't notice how old the graphics look after a while.Story:The story of this game is very simple. You are a adventurer. More specifically, you are a D&D player playing a character. You get to create your characters in this game, so you can mix and match until you find the ultimate party! You start with only two members at your table. However, you can pay gold to add three more party members. Each class has a different role. Paladin is the tank. Cleric is the healer. Mage is the support/dps and rogue is the 100% pure blood DPS. After you select your party members and their roles, you start by having your DM tell you that you are in a dark dungeon with no recollection of what happened to you previously. Now, I really don't want to spoil anymore, as fans of D&D (myself included) will have a very fun time with this game.Gameplay:This game features a turn-based system using "initiative", a real D&D mechanic. Initiative is rolled to see who gets to attack first. Say your character and an ogre were about to have a fight. Your character rolls a 15. The ogre rolls a 9. Therefore, you would get to go first, as you have the higher number. Not only is this game ROLLING in D&D references, it has it's own unique style. Locations are intresting, characters are hilarious and dialogue kept me laughing the entire time. For example, early in the game you have to kill some rats. The DM says a girl walks up to the party. One of your party members will ask, "Is she hot?" and your DM replies, "Fine. Her charisma is 19." See what I'm saying? So many tabletop references! I guess that's expected. You can upgrade your characters stats using "table items" like food or drinks. There are permanent table items, including a BK crown (which allows you to fight 7 monsters at once) and the Holy Grail (which allows you to have 5 members at your table). There are also "room upgrades". For example, on the left side of your room, you can have a suit of armor, which gives you +20 health on every character until you change it. On the right side, you can have a fridge, which makes your table items last longer. You can change your tables too. The gold table gives you more gold. The rock table gives you a larger crit chance. This game is full of customization!Music/Sounds:Music and sounds are, like the graphics, designed in a 16 bit fashion, delivering some tunes I've been humming since the day I got the game. The title screen is my personal favorite though!                                                                           OVERALL RATING:This game is a fantastic game with a lot of comedy. Over all I'd give Knights of Pen and Paper +1 Edition a 10/10 for it's effort to contribute to the D&D society and give you some good laughs along the way!Conclusion:I hope you enjoyed my review of Knights of Pen and Paper +1 Edition! The DLC for the game, Haunted Fall, is out now! I will be reviewing it once I get the chance to play the DLC! Cya next time folks!

												If you have EVER played a tabletop RPG (Dungeons and Dragons, GURPS, anything by White Wolf; or for that matter, anything where dice, paper and your imagination are required) you will be familiar with how this game operates.  Folks are around the table, One leads them in thier adventure and (sort of) asks them what they feel like doing.  The crazy part about this RPG, is that the DM and Characters are sitting around thier table as they go about thier adventure.Then, introduce EVERY NERD TROPE YOU CAN THINK OF.  Seriously, ALL OF THEM.  I saw a Tardis, Stargate and a Pyramid all in the same background.  Nothing is sacred and nothing is safe, and for that reason the game is a BLAST.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												The main knock against this game is the grind that ruins the entire experience. The whole game seems like it's built to try to get you to buy gold for real money with micro-transactions. Everything from the meager drops from enemies to the fact that you have to pay gold to upgrade the blacksmith to the fact that upgrading weapons and armor always has a failure chance requiring you to spend even more gold. Even the in-game methods of boosting your gold gain almost always come at the expense of experience which in turn prevents you from mitigating the one thing that you're most likely trying to escape from: the grind. The whole time I was playing this I could feel it reaching for my wallet... in spite of the fact that this feature has apparently been removed from the game.And this is really a shame because it's not a bad game in any other aspect. The combat is the core of the game and, while basic, it's pretty solid. I never found myself feeling overpowered or like there was no aspect of challenge to it; nor did I ever feel like the game had pushed me into a corner where I was helpless. Even though you have very few abilities to choose from, there is depth and strategy in how they're use. The pixel-art backgrounds are good and contain a lot of cool references. It's kinda cool and chilling when you go to an area to level-grind and notice after an hour that slenderman has been standing there the whole time. I personally found the humor a bit flat and irreverent... though also occasionally spot-on speaking as someone who's played the tabletop RPGs this game is supposedly an homage to.Bottom line: If you like level grinding or have a high enough tolerance for it to see the rest of the experience though then this is the game for you. For me, I've found the game too tedious to play at length and it's not worth spending hours farming gold for the meager amounts of story and the occasional chuckle. Maybe it gets better later on, but it doesn't feel worth it to me to spend the time slogging through it.And for anyone who says "This is SOOOoo much like D&D"... no, it's not. At least, not if you have a good DM it isn't. ;)

												If you like turn-based RPG's and have fond memories of pen and paper roleplaying sessions with your friends: you're going to love this game. I'm not a big fan of the recent trend for retro pixel aesthetics, but this game suits that genre.If this game had been released in the late 80's, it would have been one of those legendary classics. I think it's better than the original Final Fantasy games because it doesn't take itself seriously (it doesn't flood you with a convoluted story) and the difficulty curve is fair (it doesn't destroy you within minutes of starting).

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												Knights of Pen and Paper allows me to do something that I've always wanted to do in a fantasy setting.  I am able to control a few characters on one table with clear cut differences between them.  It is simple enough for almost anyone to understand, and it is a pretty good game to play if you like indie, small time games.  It has a lot of exploration that I haven't done.  Even though you repeat quests a lot, the quests are different every time with different people.The basis of the game is that you are playing against whatever the DM throws at you.  You are at your table, with your players and your classes they each encapsulate.  The classes are basic (Mage, Druid, Rogue, Warrior, Cleric, etc.) and the players themselves each have a special characteristic about them (the Jock has +? HP, the Alien regenrates +1 MP every turn, etc.).  It  Buying objects for the DM room, table, general location allows the players to get better points, experience, health, etc.  So instead of buffing singular characters, you are buffing all characters.  It's a fun game ultimately, and one that I will play frequently.If you don't like pixelated gfxs, or table top scenarios at all, this might not be your cup of tea.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Knights of Pen and Paper +1 is a “roleplaying game”, but in truth it has very little roleplaying in it; while this is common to many “RPGs,” this game takes it to an all-new level. The conceit behind the game is that you are sitting at a table with your game master with a group of friends, and that you are going through a campaign. The players are indeed all seated around a table, with the game master on the far side of the table dictating what is going on. It is a very clever idea, but unfortunately the game fails to execute on it at all; instead, the game is a pure hack-and-slash fest which tries to spice things up with humor and gaming references but falls flat because, quite frankly, everyone sitting around a table has already not only made all of these references, but done it better. The plot is every bad game of D&D you've ever played, every unoriginal campaign rolled into one, and it is played straight - sure, one could argue that it is almost comically bad, but it is painfully bad, like Batman and Robin, rather than camp.	As the gameplay itself is thoroughly hack and slash, purely about cutting your way through an extremely large number of monsters using extremely simplistic turn-based combat reminiscent of many JRPGs, with no real coherent or interesting story to speak of, there is little to recommend this game as anything but a time waster, and even there, you can do far better. There's nothing that this game doesn't show you in the first hour, and there's nothing in that first hour worth taking. While the basic underlying idea of having a bunch of players playing a roleplaying game is an interesting one, this game is a total failure at it. Maybe someday, someone will take this idea and do something good with it, but this is not that game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												Note that I write this review after i get the 100% completion, so the game is around 33.5 hours.Knight of Pen and Paper is actually just a role playing game. By "role playing game", i didn't mean those RPG games when you fight monsters and explore lots of places. By "role playing game", I meant the more traditional RPG, when you act as a character, imagining that you are in a different place, and do whatever you want. There are battles, of course, as it's crucial to this game.The first thing from this game that catches my eye is the art. I am a fond of pixel graphics games, and this one satisfy me. The pixels are made in a great detail. All of the assets are great looking, and the most important thing, there is no "recolored" monster at all (or i just didn't notice it), and fyi, there are tons of area to explore in this game, with different environments and monsters in most area. The music itself accompanies so well with the art, and i am never bored to listen it for long.There are tons of characters that you can choose, and tons of classes to play with, creating a party for up to 5 people, Each character has their own advantages, and each class has their own roles (dps, support, healer, tanker). You can costumize each class to your own preference because their skills can be raised with skill point which is gained every level ups. Because of this, choosing your party member can be crucial, because you can finish the game quickly or slowly depends on your setup. Also, some classes and characters need to be unlocked first, which limits your choice even more on your first playthrough. If you want to do a 100% completion, i advise you to make multiple saves, because the gold carries on each save. You can have up to 3 save slots, and although the gold is carried between saves, the accessories, equipments and levels are not.As for the battles, it's quite easy on the first part, and it becomes tougher and longer later on. You might need to grind a little or a lot depends on your setup, so make sure you get it right. Accessories also matters, because you can boost your characters quite well if you choose the right one. You can't really choose your equipments, but you can upgrade it with a success chance (well, don't worry because you can boost the chance to 100% if you have the money).Pros:- Tons of characters- Tons of classes- Tons of battles- Almost none random encounters; you can set up your own battle- Tons of maps- Tons of stories and questsCons:- Long battles- Tons of grindingShould you buy this game?If you love to grind and doesn't mind with the long battles, buy it.If you don't, then don't because it can be frustating.

I did every location 100% but had to start with recommended lvl40 fights when I was about lvl 33-34. When I was done with those I was around lvl39. And then the next quest is "kill the bad guy in this dungeon". I couldn't make it to the the boss because the boss lvl was 65. I realized that i would take hours of grind, and simply decided it wasn't worth it. I still got a great 17h from this game, so I'm still recommending it. Just wanted people to have a heads up. This game also doesn't babysit you with how you do things, most things you figure out by simply playing. Other than that this game had charming graphics, lots o references for the 90' kids. They offer a decent selection of classes to start with, but as you play this game you unlock more, up to 12 classes and 17 characters. all and all a great game but with, in my eyes one big flaw. 6/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												Note that I write this review after i get the 100% completion, so the game is around 33.5 hours.Knight of Pen and Paper is actually just a role playing game. By "role playing game", i didn't mean those RPG games when you fight monsters and explore lots of places. By "role playing game", I meant the more traditional RPG, when you act as a character, imagining that you are in a different place, and do whatever you want. There are battles, of course, as it's crucial to this game.The first thing from this game that catches my eye is the art. I am a fond of pixel graphics games, and this one satisfy me. The pixels are made in a great detail. All of the assets are great looking, and the most important thing, there is no "recolored" monster at all (or i just didn't notice it), and fyi, there are tons of area to explore in this game, with different environments and monsters in most area. The music itself accompanies so well with the art, and i am never bored to listen it for long.There are tons of characters that you can choose, and tons of classes to play with, creating a party for up to 5 people, Each character has their own advantages, and each class has their own roles (dps, support, healer, tanker). You can costumize each class to your own preference because their skills can be raised with skill point which is gained every level ups. Because of this, choosing your party member can be crucial, because you can finish the game quickly or slowly depends on your setup. Also, some classes and characters need to be unlocked first, which limits your choice even more on your first playthrough. If you want to do a 100% completion, i advise you to make multiple saves, because the gold carries on each save. You can have up to 3 save slots, and although the gold is carried between saves, the accessories, equipments and levels are not.As for the battles, it's quite easy on the first part, and it becomes tougher and longer later on. You might need to grind a little or a lot depends on your setup, so make sure you get it right. Accessories also matters, because you can boost your characters quite well if you choose the right one. You can't really choose your equipments, but you can upgrade it with a success chance (well, don't worry because you can boost the chance to 100% if you have the money).Pros:- Tons of characters- Tons of classes- Tons of battles- Almost none random encounters; you can set up your own battle- Tons of maps- Tons of stories and questsCons:- Long battles- Tons of grindingShould you buy this game?If you love to grind and doesn't mind with the long battles, buy it.If you don't, then don't because it can be frustating.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												The Definition of RepetitiveKnights of Pen & Paper has a nice theme going for it.  You are a bunch of people sitting down for a game of D&D.  Unfortunately, you have a terrible DM who fills the game with references and memes and little else.  It makes the story not only irrelevant, but obnoxious.  As an example, Nabe Gewell tasks you to get a crowbar because reasons.Moving into how the game plays, you start off being able to select a few characters and classes for you to control; more get unlocked later in the game.  Each character has their own ability and every class gets four abilities, some active, some passive.  You only get one free character to make but you can spend gold to get the full party of five.  It is recommended you do this as soon as possible since you always start at level 1, forcing a grind for them to catch up since they will easily die and dead characters gain no experience.This is where the whole repetition comes into play.  You go to an area around your level (moving areas involves clicking the area; that is it), select how many and what monsters to fight and go at it.  There are quests to complete but they are almost all kill X things or collect X things from monsters.  The rest are escorts that force a battle on every move you make, even if you vastly outlevel the area.  This is what you spend the entire game doing, even for the main quest.Good combat could have salvaged this but it is very basic.  Everyone gets a turn order slightly modified by your initiative and you end up spamming one ability per character until victory.  It is barely above the original Dragon Quest in how things operate.Even after all this, there are further glitches and issues the game has.  The quests all have levels so you can tell when they should be done, except there are several that require you kill things greatly higher than the quest level suggests.  Sometimes the quest level will even jump mid-quests, forcing you to abandon it and redo the parts you already did later.  I had level 6 quests task me going into a level 20 area as well as a level 40 area.While minor, even leveling up your own skills are slightly glitched.  I noticed several times where the game claimed leveling up a skill would give it four damage only for it to get three.  It gets even worse any time decimals are used where the game seems to forget about them in later skill ups.Knights of Pen & Paper had potential but it was ruined with its tedium and nonsense.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												I came into this game with relatively low expectations, and I am glad to say that KoPaP didn't disappoint.There's plenty of replayability and the in-jokes here and there are appreciated, but what really pulls it together is that it's actually a pretty good representation of (albeit loosely) a tabletop RPG. There's not a ton of grinding involved, but when there /is/ grinding needed, you definitely feel it. That was probably the lowest point of the game that I experienced, and even then I kept going because there was still something waiting to be explored.All in all, a very good game with a lot of untapped potential.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												A game that obliterates your grasp of time.  This game should not be initiated late in the evening as you will almost always find yourself still playing by one in the morning.  New players begin with five seats, but can only afford to fill two of them at first.  Choose carefully which skills your heroes will specialize in, don't make jack-of-all-trades; because even though you can 'usually' controll the strength of the mob parties you will fight, you can't afford to be unspecialized.   I'm loving this game so much I can barely elequate.Humor:  Casual, but usually satisfactory, 8-bit cliches and DM wit, 7/10Music: Fits the game, it's 8-bit rpg themes, what is there to say?  6/10Controls: Smoothe as giant moth fur.  In combat, whoevers turn it is, no need to click 'attack' and then select which enemy to attack, just click the enemy and, wham, a virtual 'rush' mechanic for mopping up weaker mobs.  The world map could've been given a bit more compensation room at the fringes because you click and drag the map to move it around and some locations ARE right at the edges, just a minor irritation there, could've been fixed with the ability to zoom out, but they didn't include that.  There were other things, but overall, deserves a 9/10Visuals: In an 8-bit tabletop rpg sim, all you can ask for is a great color pallete, and it's in there.  8/10This game is virtually always in Ironman mode, constantly autosaving, so even if you hit esc enough times to terminate the game, no need to freak for your progress' sake :)That's enough from me, enjoy, my comerade gamers, *drops the mic*

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Very simple game of D&D pixalated. You start off with 2 characters and you have to buy more character/seats (10, 80, 125 coins). Do go to the store and buy some exp bonus and the other store for attack bonus. The game is not really hard, but it is more of choose how many/powerful your enemies are. Choose to do side quests or explore the other areas. Just becareful of not going to the areas that are +5 level above yours or the battle will take a while. Other than that... I enjoy this game. If this game is over your price limit, get it on sale or bundled. You will enjoy it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 16
												Why the hell does this game have so many positive reviews?!The best part of A actual D&D game, is the feeling you get knowing you can do what ever/go where ever you want. Sky is the limit. Not the case here guys. You are VERY limited.:PROS:Cool Idea:CONS:You never touch A single Dice in Knights Of Pen And Paper. Every so often the game will suddenly role for meaningless nonsense, or role when clicking on location to location to determin if an enemy will spawn.Think NES game with FAR LESS story content. You CAN'T interact with the dungeon master at all. Your About as close as you can get to being locked into a set path without "technically" being locked into it. You do not make any choices in this game.There are A bunch of clsasses, which is awesome, but guess what? you can't use 70% of them unless you take the time to unlock them. So you can not even use the classes that you want to. The unlocking thing would be fine if Knights of pen and paper was A good game and engaging, but it is not. Instead you are left feeling bored/stuck with meaningless grinding, attempting to unlock your preffered class.Story telling is crap. No replay value. Not challenging at all.You never-endingly click on the map doing fetch and escort quests that are so far BEYOND boring they make me want to pull my hair out.Gold system is flawed. Farming for XP is not fun, and feels more like work. Fun is the reason we play video games. Could possibly be the shitiest RPG (wannabe) I have ever played. Gear crafting is joke. Pixel art is not very good.Music is even worse. Contains no creativity. No interaction or choices between other characters on table and DM. Very little customizationBoring Dialog, and very poorly written. :VERDICT:In no way is it A solo player D&D experience. Or even A decent rpg experience. All you do is click on sh-it with your mouse, hoping that the game will get better, but it never does.There is nothing special or unique about this game. Knights of pen and paper is not worth buying even if it is on sale. Do yourself A solid; grab some snacks, invite some friends over, and play some REAL D&D. To hell with this epic fail, wannabe, turd pile of A game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 25, 2013
												This game ate up an entire Tuesday and Wednesday for me.Seriously.  I haven't even moved.  Just sat here, playing.It's sad that some achievements are bugged and can't be gotten, otherwise I'd have 100%'d this gem.  There's micro transactions in the game but they're totally optional.  I completed the game without spending any more money on the game than the pennies I bought it for.If you like pen and paper RPGs like Dungeons and Dragons and Pathfinder, you might enjoy this tribute.  Many gaming easter eggs, some laughs, fun storyline.  Replayability? Hm.. I don't know, probably not much.  I think you'd finish it twice but that's about it.If this comes on sale, give it a go, I bought it for £4 and was highly worth it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 16
												I've only tabletopped a couple times, & the oldest D&D edition I've used was 3.5, so I'm hardly the target audience anyway. I found the combat system to be more Final Fantasy, (which I've played even less,) than D&D.There's no apparent plot, which was even less than I expected, but not actually less than advertised. Of course, I like being at least double my opponent's level, so I wouldn't be following the storyline at the proper pace anyway. I only just found where the blacksmith is, perhaps now that I can improve my weapons & armour, I'll dawdle less. Just as soon as I get my gear leveled up sufficiently.Some reviewers have complained about the boring dialog. In my experience the dialog rarely displays for sufficient time to properly notice that it's even there, let alone read it. Maybe that's why I haven't caught the plot.Pretty good for filling a few unallocated minutes, or hours of meaningless hack-n-slash. Not recommended for when you want a strong story.

content:
Posted: April 26
												Very enjoyable, addictive little game. Funny dialogue, simple PC advancement, and lots of different enemies to fight. Can get grindy and repetitive but there are some truly challenging battles thrown in for good measure. I think you will enjoy this one. If it's on sale then you really should purchase it. If not, you will be paying for its true value, which is okay too. Unlock those other classes (barbarian, shaman, witch etc.) and enjoy some replayability value.
